urn:contentItem:5WM2-FH21-F03R-W14F-00000-00Tucker Carlson Says Corporations Are Now the Biggest Threat to Your Freedom. He's Wrong2019-07-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisTucker Carlson Says Corporations Are Now the Biggest Threat to Your Freedom. He's Wrong


Sundar Pichai, Jack Dorsey, and Mark Zuckerberg have no prisons. They've never run an internment camp or seized anyone's home for failure to mow their lawn. Their body counts are a combined zero. Yet in a recent keynote address at the National Conservatism conference, Tucker Carlson suggested that big corporations-like Google, Twitter, and Facebook-are a greater threat to your freedom than the government.


"The main threat to your ability to live your life as you choose does not come from the government anymore, but it comes from the private sector," the Fox News host said.
Echoing recent praise for Senator Elizabeth Warren and her brand of economic nationalism, Carlson declared that her book on the two-income trap is "one of the best books on economics he's ever read." (Might we recommend a bit of Sowell, Hayek, or Smith?)
Is Carlson's claim defensible? Not by a long shot.
Government Abuse as a Threat to Freedom
The genius of the Constitution is a result of the American Founders' understanding that our freedoms and rights precede government and that an unrestrained government is the biggest threat to those freedoms. The Founders limited the power of the government through an intricate system of enumerated powers, separation of powers, explicit rights, and rights retained by the people to impede the abuse of governmental power.
Limiting the potential for governmental abuse was fundamental to the design of our constitutional order and remains an abiding concern. No such concern existed for "big corporations" because businesses do not wield the power to promulgate civil and criminal laws and exact punishment for violations of them. The state, not business, has a monopoly on compelled coercion.
Government has the legal authority to incarcerate you, allocate your tax dollars how it sees fit, and foreclose on your home if you fail to mow the lawn.
While laws and law enforcement are essential in a free and orderly society, government abuse at all levels has riddled our history (from FDR's internment camps to Jim Crow laws in the South) and is the stuff of daily headlines.
Government has the legal authority to incarcerate you, allocate your tax dollars how it sees fit, and foreclose on your home if you fail to mow the lawn.
You may recall the Supreme Court case Masterpiece Cakeshop v. Colorado Civil Rights Commission involving Jack Phillips, the owner of Masterpiece Cakeshop. Phillips was asked by a same-sex couple to create a wedding cake for their upcoming ceremony. Jack politely refused. A complaint was filed with the Colorado Civil Rights Commission, which led to a years-long struggle for Jack as he sought to protect his business, his brand, and his reputation. Even though the Supreme Court ultimately sided with Jack, the state of Colorado sought to punish him for exercising his freedom of speech and association.
Where Is the Evidence of Corporations Threatening Freedom?
Much of the nationalist right's recent lambasting of big business seems focused on social media. A few media personalities like Alex Jones, Louis Farrakhan, Laura Loomer, and Milo Yiannopoulos have been de-platformed for violating terms of service or community standards, but where is the widescale conservative or nationalist purge? Even when users from the right have been suspended "permanently," social media has reversed course and reinstated their accounts, sometimes within 48 hours. (Ask your attorney if you can appeal a conviction or civil judgment brought by the government within 48 hours.)
The reality is that no person has a constitutional or natural right to a social media account.
The reality is that no person has a constitutional or natural right to a social media account. A user must agree to the terms of service and comply with community standards to enjoy the services offered by these platforms. No user can compel Facebook or Twitter to tolerate what it deems hateful or offensive language any more than they can compel Fox News to give airtime to pro-Antifa screeds.
Where else is big business threatening conservatives' freedom? Are banks refusing mortgages to conservatives? Are hospitals refusing to treat them? Are auto dealers refusing to sell F150s to boomers because of MAGA memes? Certainly, there are unfortunate stories of well-known conservatives being refused service at local restaurants, but the multi-year investigation into the IRS's unfair treatment of conservative groups reveals where the greater threat lies.
"Big Business Hates Your Family"
Carlson's speech at the conference was titled "Big Business Hates Your Family." While Carlson has railed against American companies for any number of reasons in recent years, his latest bête noire is Oreo. Nabisco, a parent company of Oreo, was in Carlson's crosshairs for advertising that suggests kids "choose their pronoun" with their Pride Month "pronoun pack" cookies.
Tucker dismissed the idea that people can start their own competing business if they don't like a company's practices. This dismissal of entrepreneurship is puzzling coming from an entrepreneur; Carlson is the co-founder of an online publisher. But there is an even simpler course of action than starting your own cookie company. If you are not happy with Nabisco's business practices, buy different cookies... or bake your own at home with your family.
It's not clear what policy Carlson would suggest in response to Oreo, but Carlson's characterization of big companies as monopolies may give a clue.
Use a Scalpel, Not a Sledgehammer
Carlson has blasted social media giants as "digital monopolies."
The big digital monopolies demand that we conform to their worldview and shut us down when we dissent. They have too much power. They are are threat to this country. Congress is doing nothing about it. It's time to complain, while we still can. #Tucker @FoxNews
- Tucker Carlson (@TuckerCarlson) April 27, 2018
Despite the national media celebrity's histrionics, there are dozens of social media platforms and search engines. Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram might be the most popular for now, but if a conservative doesn't like these companies' policies, they can unplug, deactivate their account, or try other emerging platforms like Codias, MeWe, Ricochet, or an alternative search engine like DuckDuckGo.
Decrying social media companies as monopolies suggests that the companies should be broken up under antitrust laws. However, the Federal Trade Commission enforces antitrust laws where there's a showing of anti-competitive practices. It isn't enough to say that a company is too large or the company's practices are not pleasing to pundits like Carlson.
Giving users greater control over their own information would be one way to give consumers more power without breaking up the companies.
If companies like Google, Twitter, and Facebook engage in anti-competitive practices, such as price-fixing or exclusionary contracts, they should be forced to comply with applicable law like any other company. But rather than fearmongering that these companies are a greater threat to freedom than the government, we should narrowly tailor a remedy.
For instance, these tech companies' greatest competitive advantage is that they have collected extensive data over the years. Rather than trying to break up these companies, users could be given the statutory right of data portability, where a person can delete their account and take all of their personal data with them. Giving users greater control over their own information would be one way to give consumers more power without breaking up the companies they enjoy using on a regular basis.
America Needs More Capitalism, Not Less
Ultimately, it's an odd time to rail against American capitalism. Unemployment has dropped to its lowest level since 1969, and worker wages are on the rise. Capitalism, including big business, is a source of economic prosperity for American workers and families.
Rather than weaponizing antitrust prosecutions for political or social purposes, policymakers should eliminate the anti-competitive privileges of crony capitalism. Concerns about data privacy are real but can be addressed with focused remedies rather than the blunt tool of "breaking up big tech."
Americans are not at the mercy of businesses that don't share their values.
Americans are not at the mercy of businesses that don't share their values. Like Tucker Carlson, we are free to start a competing business, or we can simply choose another supplier. By contrast, we can't "log out" of laws and regulations-even ones we disagree with. Violating federal law or disobeying the instructions of a law enforcement officer can come with severe and sometimes deadly consequences.
Our Founders wisely recognized that our greatest threat isn't Nabisco or Facebook. With the memory of an overreaching British monarch fresh in their minds, they sought to establish a republic that ensured government-not private business-was properly constrained. We ignore their wisdom at our own peril.

Extracts.SummaryText: ... CARLSON: The irony alarm just goes off in the back. Tammy Bruce, great to see you. Have the best weekend. BRUCE: My pleasure. Thank you, dear. CARLSON: Billionaire and far-left patron George Soros was in Davos last week, of course. He was talking. And he called the big tech companies like Google and Facebook a menace to society. He is right about that. But then, he kept going. He said the current administration in Washington is not just bad for the country, it's an existential threat to civilization ...

urn:contentItem:5RM5-G1X1-DXH2-610K-00000-00Tucker: Russia Collusion Points To Dems, Not Republicans; "NYT": US Spies Paid $100,000 To A Russian Selling Dirt On Trump; Trump May Target Immigrants Using Food Aid; Sen. Gillibrand: Hillary Clinton Still My Greatest Role Model In Politics; Soros Slams Google And Facebook; Are Antidepressants Harming Americans?; "Final Exam"2018-02-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisTUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT8:00 PM ESTPhilippe Reines, Kim Strassel, Jose Aristimuno, Tammy Bruce, Steve Hilton, Johann HariNEWSInternational020901cb.260Tucker: Russia Collusion Points To Dems, Not Republicans; "NYT": US Spies Paid $100,000 To A Russian Selling Dirt On Trump; Trump May Target Immigrants Using Food Aid; Sen. Gillibrand: Hillary Clinton Still My Greatest Role Model In Politics; Soros Slams Google And Facebook; Are Antidepressants Harming Americans?; "Final Exam"Tucker Carlson, Ed Henry, Carley Shimkus

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST, TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT.

There is an awful lot going on. Just minutes ago, the White House released a letter saying the president is inclined to declassify that Democratic committee memo and will work with the House Intelligence Committee to see if they can come up with a releasable version of it, much redacted.

But that is not the only breaking news tonight. There is a lot more. The Russia story has suddenly become an FBI story and it's moving faster than anyone anticipated.

Just a year ago, all the smart people were mocking Donald Trump for being insane enough to suggest the Obama administration had surveilled or, as he put it, wiretapped his campaign. What a paranoid lunatic, they said. Get off Twitter.

Yes, now we know what actually happened. The question, at this point is, how many people in Trump's orbit weren't spied on by the FBI? Trump advisor Carter Page was placed under government surveillance in the fall of 2016 after the feds used uncorroborated claims from the Trump dossier to justify a FISA warrant.

We know from congressional testimony that Page spoke with Trump advisor, Trump campaign manager Steve Bannon while he was being spied on. Meaning that Bannon was likely spied on, too.

Tonight, based on our own reporting, we can tell you that Carter Page also sent email messages to members of the Trump campaign during that same period. Presumably, the FBI intercepted those as well. Suddenly, it looks like the Obama administration may have spied on a significant portion of the Trump campaign team.

Just how many people were surveilled and to what extent? How much did President Obama know about it? We still don't have the answers to those questions. Though we definitely have the right to them.

Oh, no, we don't, say Democrats. Asking questions is a sign of disloyalty to this country. The very people who once told us that spying absolutely never happened are now telling us that spying was perfectly justified and normal. Why? Because Russia.

OK. But the funny thing is almost all of the Russian collusion evidence unearthed recently implicates Democrats. Not the Trump campaign. Yesterday, we learned that, for example, Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia was secretly sending text messages to a lobbyist for a Russian oligarch in the hope of making contact with the dossier author Christopher Steele.

Warner tried to hide that correspondence. I'd "rather not have a paper trail," he texted to the oligarch's lobbyist.

Now, traditionally, Washington, anyway, no paper trail is not an indicator of transparency. In fact, it's a sign of wrongdoing.

Now, we are not saying that Sen. Warner ought to resign his seat and face treason charges and we are not saying that because we are not hysterical liberals willing to poison our international relations and misuse the justice system just for cheap political ends. But we do think that Warner's behavior is worth knowing more about.

And so, by the way, is a remarkable new "New York Times" story just published about 40 minutes ago. That story alleges that, within the last year, American intelligence agencies paid a spy, apparently a spy working for the Russian government, $100,000 in American tax dollars in exchange for unverified and possibly fabricated information about President Trump.

Now, why would our intelligence agencies use our money to do something like that? Why would they do anything like that under any circumstances. And, by the way, what was the information they gathered used for?

None of that is clear at this hour. Here's what is clear right now. The bottom line in what we've learned this whole week, the one thing worth taking away from a dramatic week in Washington is this, the Obama administration spied on a rival political campaign. There had better be a legitimate reason for doing that. But, increasingly, it looks like there wasn't.

Fox chief national correspondent Ed Henry joins us with more on that Russia intel story. Ed?

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Well, Tucker, this is just breaking this hour. "The New York Times" reporting that a shadowy Russian tricked American spies actually out of 100 grand last year.

They promised not just information on Donald Trump, but to deliver stolen national security agency cyber weapons in a deal that this shadowy Russian insisted would also include, yes, compromising material on the president. Sounds like a spy novel.

The NSA has been devastated by losing these secret hacking tools. So, they delivered the cash in a suitcase to a Berlin hotel room in September. Supposed to be the first installment of a million-dollar payout.

Here's the kicker. The Russian claimed the information would link the president and his associates to Russia. But, instead of providing the hacking tools, the Russian produced unverified and possibly fabricated information involving Mr. Trump and others. Bank records, emails, purported Russian intelligence data. Sounds a little bit like the Steele dossier.

Several US intel officials tell us tonight they made clear they did not want the Trump material from the Russians. They are insisting they never wanted this. He was suspected of having murky ties to Russian intel and to Eastern European cyber criminals. That's what they tell "The New York Times". But it sounds like US intel officials are spinning after the fact because they were in negotiations.

The NSA even used its official Twitter account nearly a dozen times to send out coded messages to this Russian. The Russian's eagerness to sell the Trump dirt raised suspicion among American spies because it was part of an operation to feed the information out into the United States intelligence community and pit US intel officials against Mr. Trump.

It was confusing because, at one point, this Russian dropped his asking price from $10 million to just over $1 million. That raised alarm bells.

Then he showed a 15-second clip of a video showing a man in a room talking to two women. He claimed it was Mr. Trump. But there was really no way to confirm that it was Mr. Trump with two women. It was a grainy video. It had no audio. And we are told that these officials were shown the video in the Russian embassy in Berlin.

So, this does sound like a spy novel. And as you were just saying, the president some time ago was suggesting that some US intel officials were out to get him. People said this is crazy. That wouldn't happen.

But now "The Times" is reporting tonight a remarkable story suggesting that they were willing to pay a million dollars to potentially get dirt on the president. US Intelligence officials.

They gave $100,000, the first installment, and the shadowy Russian took the money, went away without any dirt on the president. Tucker?

CARLSON: Pretty unbelievable. Actually shocking. Very badly written story. But you, I thought, summarized it very well.

Philippe Reines was a longtime advisor to Hillary Clinton, was deputy assistant secretary of state under Obama and he joins us tonight. Philippe, thanks for coming on.

PHILIPPE REINES, FORMER SENIOR ADVISOR TO HILLARY CLINTON: Thank you.

CARLSON: So, I've just got to ask you, to the extent you know about this story that just broke, but the bottom line is our intelligence community paid $100,000 to apparently a Russian agent for salacious information of sexual nature, unverified, likely false, about President Trump. That doesn't seem standard.

REINES: Well, you know what? I think it's a couple things on why it does sound like a spy novel. Unfortunately, it's nonfiction. It's what we are living through.

I think the intelligence agencies often have to pay people who are not great to get information. We paid $8 million to find out who the worst spy in FBI history was, Robert Hanssen. I think we paid $25 million to locate Khalid Sheikh Mohammed.

CARLSON: Yes. For sure. And I'm glad that we did.

REINES: I'm glad, too. But I think this is an example of it working because I don't know when this is from, but you know what, you haven't heard about it, and that's because it was debunked, exactly as Ed was saying.

CARLSON: Well, I don't know. Look, there is a lot that we don't know and I don't want to presume anything ever. But the bottom line is, our government paid $100,000 of our money to buy fake salacious material about the president. What would be the national security reason for doing that?

REINES: I think the bottom line is that the president's campaign was stocked with people, starting with Carter Page, who, by the way, was under FBI surveillance going back to 2013. Nothing to do with the president's campaign.

His contacts warranted multiple surveillance warrants. Starting on October of 2016, four more times. And mind you, do the math. Four more times takes you into the Trump administration.

CARLSON: I'm aware of that. And you, like a lot of people who have abandoned concerns about civil liberties, are assuming that because someone is under surveillance, he has done something wrong, whereas I would argue that the onus is on the government to explain why you are spying on Americans.

REINES: I think most people agree with you. I certainly agree with you and the FISA court has a very high bar.

CARLSON: No, it actually doesn't. And we know that because almost no applications for FISA warrants are ever turned down.

REINES: But there are very few ever made because everyone knows -

CARLSON: OK. This is the chicken and the egg. But the truth is they are almost never turned down. And we know that, in this case, the dossier was the backbone of the request. It was the first thing in the request. We do know that.

And we know that the dossier by the FBI's own description was a flakey document, whose contents they could not verify.

So, look, here's the bottom line. Does it bother you - if I said during the Obama administration that the Bush administration during the campaign had spied on a bunch of members of Obama's campaign team.

REINES: Not that they were suspected of Russian agents.

CARLSON: But what if a year-and-a-half later, there was no evidence that they were Russian agents? Would you say, well, geez, before you spy on a rival political campaign using the FBI, you better be sure you've got good reason.

REINES: That is an interesting argument. Is Carter Page part of the Trump campaign or not? You'd make it sound like he was the running mate, except when it comes to his contacts -

CARLSON: He didn't have anything to do with the Trump campaign.

REINES: So, it's not looking at the Trump campaign.

CARLSON: No, no. Here's the point. Look, Carter Page - this show exclusively learned today - emailed a number of people on the Trump campaign.

REINES: That's called surveillance.

CARLSON: Right. And so, if you are surveying Carter Page who never got paid - he says he never met Trump, Trump says he never met him, whatever. I wasn't there, but that's what we know about it. I don't think he was integral to the campaign. But he had contact with people on the campaign.

And all of his conversations, both written and verbal, were being surveilled by the federal government.

REINES: That's what surveillance is. (INAUDIBLE) of what you're doing. He's probably talking to his dentist too.

CARLSON: But what this means is the Obama administration is spying on the Trump campaign.

REINES: No. They are not.

CARLSON: They actually literally were.

REINES: The Obama administration thankfully took this very seriously. They went and got a warrant on someone. The warrant was based on George Papadopoulos. The dossier was part of the warrant, but the warrant was primarily -

CARLSON: That's not true. That's not true.

But the point is, I'm just saying. Let's be totally honest here. The Obama administration spying on the Trump campaign, maybe there is an awesome reason for it, no one has explained that yet. But you assume that it's totally fine. You would not assume it was totally fine it was flipped around, would you?

REINES: I would assume - I happen to trust our government. I know that these days that's not a very savvy thing to say.

CARLSON: I've always trusted our government.

REINES: I trust it whether it's President Bush or President Obama. FISA started in earnest after 9/11. And I think we all learned that it was important. And if American citizens are, in some way, acting as a foreign agent, then they are fair game. I'm sorry they are fair game.

CARLSON: But you have to prove that they are and they didn't. And by the way, there is no reason based on everything we have learned in the past couple of weeks to have child-like faith in our intelligence agencies. And I don't think it's a good idea.

REINES: But bear in mind, with Carter Page, that it was renewed every 90 days three times. But it was renewed based on what happened in those 90 days.

CARLSON: Let's see the applications.

REINES: I'm happy for that. Unfortunately, I don't control it.

CARLSON: I don't either. Philippe, thank you.

REINES: No, thank you, Tucker.

CARLSON: Kim Strassel is on "The Wall Street Journal" editorial board. She follows the subject very closely and she joins us tonight.

So, Kim, I hate to hit with a story that's just come out because neither of us knows that much about it. But I just want your reaction since you cover this.

We learn in "The New York Times" piece 50 minutes ago that US intel agencies under the Trump administration paid 100 grand to get salacious information and apparently false information on Trump. Does that sound kind of just like normal business as usual to you?

REINES: No. It does not. Because as was just noted, it's one thing to go out and spend money potentially getting information on a sworn enemy of the United States. It's another to go out and spend $100,000 trying to get information on the commander-in-chief.

CARLSON: Yes. I mean, presumably - according to "The Times" piece, it wasn't information that suggested he was selling secrets to anybody. It was information of a sexual nature that's probably not even true. But like it's also irrelevant to American national security.

Let me ask you this. Do you find it striking that the very people who a year ago said anyone who claims Trump was spied on by the Obama administration is a nutcase or Alex Jones or whatever tinfoil hat type. Those same people are now telling us, like, yes, of course, it's totally normal for one administration to spy on a rival presidential campaign. Like, no big deal.

STRASSEL: This is the story of this entire investigation, Tucker. Think back. First, we are told that the dossier was a creation of Republican funder. Turns out it was the Clinton campaign and the DNC.

Then we are told that it couldn't possibly have been used as part of a FISA warrant. Turns out it was. Then we are told it couldn't have made a big part of it. It turns out it was the main piece.

Now, we are told, well, it doesn't really matter because it wasn't really spying on the Trump campaign. It was spying on a man who had already left the campaign. Only that's not true either. It turns out it was used to end up following the conversations of Carter Page and whomever else he might have been talking to.

Steve Bannon, who has been mentioned, is potentially only one. There could be many other people that they managed to capture because of this.

CARLSON: So, how can - I mean, it seems to me it's critical in order to restore faith in government that we know the details here. Or else, in the vacuum created by ignorance, conspiracy theories grow. So, like, how do we get to the bottom of what actually happened?

STRASSEL: Well, look, for instance, at what happened when Sen. Grassley put out a less redacted version of his referral letter of a criminal investigation of Christopher Steele. You know, we were told none of that could come out, it would damage sources, methods, highly classified.

You look at it and you find out that the only thing that was, in fact, redacted was information that was highly scandalous and hurtful to the FBI that undermined it and the Justice Department.

So, my question is, why shouldn't we put out these FISA applications? Let's put out all the documents and see where the skeletons are. And, yes, we can try to be careful of sources and methods. But this has now become a force of he said, she said. And the American public deserves to see it and judge it with their own eyes.

CARLSON: Yes. The embarrassment of federal bureaucrats is not justification for keeping something secret. It doesn't belong to them. They don't own these documents. They belong to us.

So, Kim Strassel, thanks for reminding of us of all that. It was great.

STRASSEL: Thank you.

CARLSON: Trump administration planning to enforce laws that keep immigrants off welfare. Those laws have been on the books for a long time. Of course, progressives are outraged. As always. That story next.

CARLSON: Federal law has long stipulated that immigrants cannot arrive in the United States and receive permanent residency if they become "public charges" who depend upon welfare. Of course, we spend decades learning that the government treats immigration law as strictly optional.

The Trump administration is looking to change that. The administration is drafting a new regulation that would penalize immigrants for receiving welfare programs like food stamps, Section 8, Head Start and CHIP, the Children's Health Insurance Program. The left, of course, is howling.

Jose Aristimuno is a former press secretary for the Democratic National Committee and he joins us tonight. Jose, thanks for coming on.

JOSE ARISTIMUNO, DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL COMMITTEE FORMER PRESS SECRETARY: Good to be here.

CARLSON: So, what I find so interesting about the complaints here is that we know - I know from doing the show every night and speaking to immigration advocates that there are no immigrants on welfare. They are the most impressive people in our society. Add the most to our economy. They're the hardest working. None of them is a drain on the system.

And so, given that - I think you told me that too. Who cares if it's illegal for them to go on welfare? Why would they be on welfare if they are adding so much to our economy?

ARISTIMUNO: This is the issue, Tucker. And it's this. We shouldn't be punishing immigrants, legal immigrants, right, who pay taxes into our economy. Number one, if they are paying taxes, they should be able to have benefits of social programs such as Head Start. So, we are now going to punish.

CARLSON: Why? Why should they?

ARISTIMUNO: Let me tell you. We are now going to punish, US children, right, who were born in this country, we are not going to allow them to go into Head Start because parents, right, illegal immigrants, are not going to want to put him in programs like Head Start because they're going to be afraid that they're going to be deported.

CARLSON: OK. But, look, it's really simple. I'm sure that there are lot of immigrants who want these programs. I get it, they will be unhappy with it. But the point is pleasing American citizens since it's our country, not theirs.

ARISTIMUNO: These children are US citizens.

CARLSON: That's great. OK. But the truth is, we can probably figure out how to do that for the children. But I'm not talking - I mean, you are picking a tiny percentage of this.

ARISTIMUNO: But it's an important percentage.

CARLSON: Well, OK. Fine. Let's figure out a fix. But most immigrant families are on welfare. This is one of the things that advocates like you never admit when they're lecturing us that they're so much more impressive than you are. Most are.

And if you break it down by country, the last numbers I have from 2009, the federal numbers, but some countries like 70 percent of the immigrants are on welfare. So, why would you be in favor of that if you are an American citizen? Bringing people in and putting them right on benefits. That is not the American dream that we hear about at all.

ARISTIMUNO: Look, the immigration system in the United States is clearly broken. If you want to come and apply the legal way in the United States, you already go under a bunch of tests that define if you are going to be a public charge.

If you are go going to come into the United States, you should not be a public charge. You and I agree on that. But I think what the president is doing wrong he is expanding the tests. He's making it even harder for immigrants.

CARLSON: Here are the numbers. Maybe it will change your mind on this. OK, this is from the current population survey from March 2010, OK? Here are the numbers from Mexico. Mexico is the country that sends the most immigrants to the United States. By far.

Seventy-four-point-seven percent, as of 2009, immigrants from Mexico are on some form of welfare in the United States. Round up. That's 75% of all immigrants from Mexico are on some kind of welfare. That's ridiculous. And I think you just said you agreed that that was ridiculous.

ARISTIMUNO: We can change that.

CARLSON: So, why not just fix that right now and say, look, if you want to be here and add to the sum total of the economy, great. But you can't come and go on our social programs. You can't have open borders and a welfare state, right?

ARISTIMUNO: Look, you and I agree on that. This is the issue. US citizen children are being punished because of this regulation coming into place.

CARLSON: Then take - leave everyone, just let the kids get go to on Head Start, which, by the way, has never been shown to work in 50 years. So, I'm not even sure you'd want that. Honestly.

But whatever. Let's just talk about the real problem, which is the majority of immigrants are on welfare. Why would any country put up with that and why would the left defend it? I'm totally confused.

ARISTIMUNO: We are a country of laws and we are a country of immigrants. A majority of immigrants in this country are not criminals. You know that.

CARLSON: But I'm not saying they are criminals. I'm not saying the majority are criminals. I'm saying, the majority are on welfare. And that's not healthy. Because the whole idea is you move here and you take advantage of the opportunities.

ARISTIMUNO: We are now going to make it harder for them to assimilate into the country. That doesn't make any sense.

CARLSON: Going on welfare is not assimilation. Going on welfare is dependency. Look, some of the people need to go on welfare. We've got a lot of Americans on welfare.

ARISTIMUNO: Right.

CARLSON: Why would we import people from other countries on welfare. That's insane, isn't it?

ARISTIMUNO: I understand what you are getting at. But the problem is that the regulations that the president wants to put forth are not doing the point that you're trying to make. The point that we are trying to make as Democrats, the majority of Democrats is that children are being punished.

And guess what? We're now going to punish immigrants because they are poor?

CARLSON: What do you mean punish them because they are poor? They are coming to our country. It's not their country.

ARISTIMUNO: In search of a better life.

CARLSON: In search of a better life and then going on our welfare programs? Are you joking? This is not the bring us your poor, tired, huddled masses that we're told about where people come here and work their way up and run a tech company in Silicon Valley. This is like the opposite of what we want.

I think you would agree, but you are defending it for some reason. I don't know why.

ARISTIMUNO: Because it's coming from a bad place. The regulations are coming from an anti-immigrant racist agenda that the president has put forth.

CARLSON: You know what? When you guys have nothing left to say, you just, oh, it's race. If you don't give us everything we want, you are racist.

I really kind of want to move to, like, Mexico and start accusing the authorities there of racism because they are not giving me free stuff. Seriously.

I'm talking about a president that has talked about people -

CARLSON: I don't care what the president - I'm an American.

ARISTIMUNO: Well, he's the president of the United States.

CARLSON: OK. But I have a right to have some say, every American citizen does -

ARISTIMUNO: We all do, right.

CARLSON: Right. And, like, this is insane. It's not about whether the president is a racist or not. That's not a real answer, is it?

ARISTIMUNO: So, the answer is let's end chain migration, as you guys like to call it, right? Let's end the visa lottery.

CARLSON: No. Let's just have control over who comes here.

ARISTIMUNO: Let's destroy the legal immigration system, right, and deport 11 million people. Is that what we want to do?

CARLSON: I think we should have control of who lives here. I mean it. Why wouldn't you? We are a country. And if that means deporting who shouldn't be here, that's our right.

ARISTIMUNO: You and I agree on that.

CARLSON: No, you don't. You don't. You are not being honest. I'm sorry. You don't agree because you argue Trump is a racist. OK.

ARISTIMUNO: He is.

CARLSON: Yes, whatever. Thanks, Jose. Appreciate it.

George Soros was at Davos. Soros, Davos, try to read that in a script. Two weeks ago, he blasted tech companies for hurting the world. He is right about that. But there are other problems. And we'll tell you what they are.

Of course, we will continue to follow tonight's breaking news. The White House says the president intends to release the Democratic FBI memo, but needs to work with the intel committee on edits. We will continue to follow that story and tell you what's true.

CARLSON: Well, in an interview with "60 Minutes" over on "CBS", New York Senator Kirsten Gillibrand says that, even though, she recently denounced Bill Clinton as a sexual predator, his wife, Hillary Clinton somehow remains her greatest political role model, which is confusing, which is why we called Tammy Bruce, the New York radio show host, to sort it all out for us. And she joins us tonight.

Tammy, what does that mean?

TAMMY BRUCE, NEW YORK RADIO SHOW HOST: It means that, obviously, Kirsten Gillibrand doesn't know what she is talking about or she's operating exclusively politically.

Look, Hillary Clinton is the enabler of Bill Clinton. She is, of course, now we know revealed as someone who protected a sexual harasser and disrupted the work life of the victim in order to shield that individual. It's a remarkable admission.

And, yet, of course, it's completely political. If Kirsten Gillibrand cared about the issues, she couldn't even really associate with the Clintons. She is denying in this interview coming up, by the way, Tucker.

She's asked if she's spoken to the Clintons. She wouldn't answer that, but then that's when she said she admired Hillary Clinton. So, it's very strange. She doesn't want to say that she is speaking to them, but that she needs to be able to at least give her some compliments.

It could be that there is no leadership in the Democratic Party and Kirsten is wondering what kind of national base could she latch on to for this. So, that probably is part of it.

But I think she should be careful about being seen as a public face of the #MeToo movement, which now is becoming completely politicized, and I think that's bad news for that movement.

CARLSON: So, she, obviously, thinks she is going to be president. She is running for president. This interview is part of the PR preparatory to that. It seems like maybe everyone running for president should take at least one lesson from the Trump campaign, which is voters will put up with a lot if they think you are just being honest.

BRUCE: Right.

CARLSON: That phoniness is transparent. Everyone likes it, nobody appreciates it. Why hasn't she learned that? It just seems so false to me.

BRUCE: Well, I think it's because there are bubbles. Look, she's a New York Democrat. She might not even see herself as president, but perhaps as vice president. So, she is setting herself up to move beyond.

Clearly, the Democrats are deluded. If their leadership are the Clintons, no wonder they are in trouble. And she sees that somehow this is some way to move herself ahead of the game.

In California, there is a democrat, a woman who is also the face of the #MeToo movement who has now taken leave because of sexual harassment allegations against her by men. So, we're looking at a very unique dynamic. But I think the American people see through it and I think Kirsten Gillibrand is in for a little bit of a wake-up call coming up.

CARLSON: The irony alarm just goes off in the back. Tammy Bruce, great to see you. Have the best weekend.

BRUCE: My pleasure. Thank you, dear.

CARLSON: Billionaire and far-left patron George Soros was in Davos last week, of course. He was talking. And he called the big tech companies like Google and Facebook a menace to society. He is right about that.

But then, he kept going. He said the current administration in Washington is not just bad for the country, it's an existential threat to civilization itself. Civilization itself.

Steve Hilton hosts "The Next Revolution" here on "Fox 9" every Sunday night. Fantastic show. He does not agree with this assessment. And he joins us tonight from California. Hey, Steve.

STEVE HILTON, "FOX 9" HOST, "THE NEXT REVOLUTION": It's just so laughable. Look, we both agree with Soros that the tech companies are a menace to society. But he forgot to tell us that he invested in the tech companies. It is so laughable.

The things he said were so offensive to me - I can get away with this because I, like George Soros, am a Hungarian. So, I can call him a Hungarian hypocrite. Not just for the fact that he criticizes the tech companies while investing in them, he went on about gambling.

While back in the UK when I got my start in politics, he made his billions gambling in the foreign exchange markets which crashed the economy and caused untold misery for millions of people.

But when it comes to this question of the open society that he argues Donald Trump is wrecking, he really should know better because he and I share experience of that.

Communism in Hungary, that's a real attack on the open society. It's so disgusting for him to make that comparison.

CARLSON: Well, it is disgusting. But it's of a peace with his behavior over decades as just you pointed out. But since you follow this guy pretty closely, and I think you are great at big-picture things, we just learned that he is paying - giving campaign money to district attorney races around the country. And he's doing a lot of other things. What ties them all together? What's is his vision? What does he want for America? What's the point of all this?

HILTON: I think he - you know what I really think is the simple answer to that? I think it's guilt. I think he is guilty at the way he's made his money, gambling in the casino of the financial markets. And he is trying to atone for that.

A lot of the liberal elite are exactly in that position. And again, it comes to hypocrisy. The Hungarian hypocrite. He, like all the other liberal elite, jump up and down and go on about dark money in politics and the evil Koch Brothers, and yet he is doing exactly this.

It's not that he is supporting this particular candidate in these rather obscure around the country, he's actually effectively covering it up. Those donations are not made public to the electorate before the election.

CARLSON: Good point.

HILTON: And this is exactly the kind of corruption in politics that the rest of the time they love to condemn. I took a look, by the way, Tucker. The candidate certainly didn't want to recognize the contribution of her big benefactor.

She said thank you to a lot of people after her campaign. Someone called Sherri Murphy (ph), your help was major. Her local progress family, the EO network (ph), whatever that is. And even, wait for it, Tucker, your favorite publication, "Teen Vogue". This candidate thanks "Teen Vogue", but not George Soros who basically handed her her position on a plate.

CARLSON: Amazing. Everything that Soros pays for in this country makes America weaker and more divided. That seems to be a connection to me. Steve Hilton, great to see you.

Steve's show, "The Revolution", every Sunday night 9 p.m. Eastern. I watch it. You should too.

America is a depressed country. Tens of millions of Americans are taking pills for depression. Is it working? Is there another way? We'll meet an author of a brand-new book, who says there is. Really interesting conversation. Just ahead.

CARLSON: The president has announced his choice for the nation's next drug czar. His name is Jim Carroll. He's currently White House deputy chief of staff. He will be leaving to direct the office of national drug control policy. He suddenly has grave significance in the middle of this nation's worst drug epidemic.

The move, another departure from Trump's West Wing in the wake of staff secretary Rob Porter's resignation earlier this week.

Antidepressants are more popular than ever in this country. Virtually ubiquitous. According to CDC report last year, about 1 in 8 Americans reported recent antidepressant use. And yet, the nation's suicide rate has surged and the country doesn't seem to be that much happier than countries than countries that have fewer drugs in circulation.

That raises the question, are we thinking about depression in the wrong way. the author of "Lost Connections: Uncovering the Real Causes of Depression - and the Unexpected Solutions". A book that unexpectedly has become the center of a lot of debates and has sold quite well. He joins us tonight. Johann, thanks for coming on.

JOHANN HARI, AUTHOR, "LOST CONNECTIONS: UNCOVERING THE REAL CAUSES OF DEPRESSION - AND THE UNEXPECTED SOLUTIONS": Hi, Tucker. It's great to be with you.

CARLSON: So, this book has been very controversial, I think, in the best way, in that it's forced a conversation where there should have been one years ago.

But summarize for us, if you could, crisply, what is the case that you are making about antidepressants.

HARI: Yes. Most of the book is not about antidepressants. It's about why we are in such pain in the first place.

And I think that everyone watching the show knows that they have natural physical needs, right? You need water, you need food, you need shelter. If I took them away from you, you'd be in real trouble real fast.

CARLSON: Yes.

HARI: There's equally strong evidence that human beings have natural psychological needs. Overwhelming evidence. You've got to feel you belong. You've got to feel your life has meaning and purpose. You've got to feel that people see you and value you. You've got to feel that there is a future that makes sense to you.

And our culture is good at lots of things. But there's very strong evidence we have been getting less and less good at meeting people's deep underlying psychological needs. And that is one of the key drivers of this depression and anxiety crisis.

What we've been told up to now - when I was a teenager and I went to my doctor in a real sense of profound pain, my doctor said - told me a totally biological story about why I was depressed. He was just due to a chemical imbalance in my brain.

And I drugged myself for 13 years. I remained depressed. There are other people who've taken antidepressants who do experience benefit.

But one of the things that was so striking to me when I went and traveled all over the world and to meet the leading experts in the world about what really causes depression and anxiety and what really solves them is that, overwhelmingly, it's due to responses - it's a response to key factors in how we're living.

I learned the scientific evidence -

CARLSON: Well, I'm just laughing because it seems so obviously.

HARI: Yes.

CARLSON: Why have we been telling ourselves that it is mysterious chemical imbalance. Those do exist, of course. But for the overwhelming majority, maybe it has to do with the way that we are living, is making us unhappy.

HARI: Yes. If you are depressed and anxious, you are not crazy. You are not a machine with broken parts. You are a human being with unmet needs.

So, that can sound a bit strange in the abstract. So, I'll give you an obvious example that connects people immediately. There's a study that asks the average American how many close friends do you have that you could call on a crisis.

And when they started doing years ago, the most common answer was five. Today, the most common answer is none. So, we are -

CARLSON: None?

HARI: It's not the average. It's the most common answer. So, we've become the loneliest society that's ever been.

And what I want to look was what are antidepressants for these nine deep underlying causes of depression and anxiety, what are the solutions to these problems? I'll give you an example to that one.

There is a doctor in East London called Sam Everington, had loads of patients coming to him acutely depressed and anxious. And he felt really uncomfortable because he had been told in his training, even though he knew the science was much more sophisticated, to say you've just got a chemical imbalance in your brain and just give them drugs.

Like me, he is not opposed to the drugs, but he could see this wasn't solving the problem. A lot of them, for example, were acutely lonely.

He did an experiment. A woman came to him called Lisa Cunningham. She'd been shut away in her home for seven years with really severe depression and anxiety.

He said, Lisa, I'll keep giving you the drugs, don't worry. I'm also going to prescribe something else. I'm going to prescribe for you to take part in a group. There was an area of scrub land behind the doctor's surgery. And he said, we'll come and support you, but I want you to meet with a group of depressed and anxious people twice a week. And we're going to turn this into a beautiful garden. They met over weeks and months.

As Lisa put it to me, as the garden began to bloom, we began to bloom. A study of a very similar program found it's more than twice as effective as chemical antidepressants.

What I learned all over the world is there are people who are trying anti- depressants that are about dealing with the deep social and psychological reasons why we feel so terrible in the first place.

CARLSON: So, the deeper question is - everything you said is so obvious to me. Reports are (ph) completely with our experience as people. We're are out of time, but maybe you can come back and explain why we vest so much unwarranted faith in psychiatrists. Why are we so willing to take bad advice from people with MDs.

HARI: We've only given those psychiatrists one lever to pull. So, in one way, you can't blame them for pulling it. But what we need to do as a society is put in place a much more expanded menu of options. Things that actually deal with these nine deep reasons why we feel so terrible in the first place. And those options exist. They've been tried all over the world. I've seen them. And they're reducing depression and anxiety. They give a lot of hope.

CARLSON: I believe you completely. The book is "Lost Connections: Uncovering the Real Causes of Depression - and the Unexpected Solutions." I'm reading the title, so people will buy it. I think it's great.

Johann, thank you.

HARI: Thank you so much, Tucker.

"Final Exam" is next. Have you been following the news more closely than our news professionals? You can find out in just a minute.

CARLSON: Time now for "Final Exam" where we pit two news professionals here at Fox against one another to determine who has been paying closer attention to the news of the past week.

Our three-time defending champion here for a fourth week Carley Shimkus, "Fox News Headline 24/7" reporter and contributor to "Fox & Friends." Her challenger this week, (INAUDIBLE) Fox chief national correspondent Ed Henry.

HENRY: Big title.

CARLSON: Who was on the show last night in a very different context.

CARLEY SHIMKUS, "FOX NEWS HEADLINE 24/7" REPORTER: He is a heavyweight.

HENRY: Yes, literally.

CARLSON: He's smart. But we'll see. No one has been able to stop Carley so far.

OK. Put your hands on the buzzers. I'm going to go through the rules. You know what they are. I ask the questions. The first one to buzz in gets to answer. You have to wait until I finish the question in order to do that. Every correct answer is worth a point. Get it wrong, we subtract a point. Best of five wins.

Ready?

SHIMKUS: I think we can handle that.

CARLSON: All right.

SHIMKUS: We'll see.

CARLSON: Good luck.

SHIMKUS: Thank you.

CARLSON: A 13-year-old went viral during Justin Timberlake's halftime show at the Super Bowl because he seemed very distracted. What was he doing? Ed Henry.

HENRY: He was on his phone. He took a selfie with Justin Timberlake, but there was something - he was watching a video and it broke down or something. So, he got teased.

CARLSON: That's a long answer. Does the tape -

HENRY: He was on "Ellen". I saw him on "Ellen".

CARLSON: We're going to roll the tape and find out.

SHIMKUS: Interesting information.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Meme of 13-year-old Ryan McKenna stealing the spotlight, poking fun at the teenager for staring at his phone too much while the pop star was right next to him.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I thought the kid should have taken the selfie with Justin behind him and then put his phone down and enjoy the show. Just like what we all do. Everyone has got to have their phone and tape everything.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Well, that's a very unclear answer.

SHIMKUS: No. I dispute that.

CARLSON: But our judges are saying he got it.

HENRY: He was on his phone. He said on "Ellen" or "Good Morning America" that he was watching a video and said he got teased because the phone broke down.

CARLSON: So, you are watching both "Ellen" and "Good Morning America"?

HENRY: Yes.

CARLSON: OK. Let's talk later about that. OK.

SHIMKUS: All right.

CARLSON: Question two, a world leader made news this week when he chastised a woman for using the phrase "mankind" which is a sexist phrase in his country. This leader recommends more inclusive terms like peoplekind. Who was it?

HENRY: Wait, she did it - he hadn't finished.

SHIMKUS: All right.

CARLSON: Judges? He finished says the judges.

SHIMKUS: That would be Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

CARLSON: Not, Justin Timberlake. Justin Trudeau.

SHIMKUS: Justin Trudeau. The other JT.

CARLSON: The other JT. Here we go.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST, "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT": Prime minister Justin Trudeau is really serious about making Canadians watch their language.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Maternal love is the love that's going to change the future of mankind.

JUSTIN TRUDEAU, PRIME MINISTER OF CANADA: We like to say peoplekind, not necessarily mankind. That's more inclusive.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHIMKUS: Very inclusive.

CARLSON: Yes.

SHIMKUS: He's an inclusive guy.

CARLSON: So, let me just say that our judges - look, I'm not sure why they make the decisions they do. But you don't ask those kind of questions. This is a very hierarchal show. The judges are in charge. Here we go, it's 1-1.

HENRY: Do you have certain number of challenges?

CARLSON: No, I don't. I never challenge. Question three, which 77-year- old lawmaker just set a record for the longest continuous speech in the history of the House of Representatives causing some of her colleagues to dozen off in their chairs? Carley Shimkus?

SHIMKUS: That would be Nancy Pelosi.

CARLSON: Nancy Pelosi. I don't think she is 77, but we'll find out. Check the tape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS HOST, "INGRAHAM ANGLE": And Nancy Pelosi, oh, she punishes - I mean, promotes the Dreamers with a marathon 8-hour speech. Good for her. 4-inch heels, too. Lent has come early.

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST, "WATTERS WORLD": Even Democrats aren't happy with the minority leader's performance. One of Nancy's colleagues fell asleep during the speech.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHIMKUS: That's understandable, right? Eight hours.

CARLSON: OK. Our judges concede - sort of back end of this, can see the metrics, say that you buzzed in just milliseconds before your competitor.

HENRY: So, it doesn't count?

CARLSON: No, no. It does count. It does count.

HENRY: Wait. So, you could break the rules?

CARLSON: No, I was just complimenting for her (INAUDIBLE) reaction.

HENRY: But you can bend the rules. OK.

CARLSON: She is fast. All right. Question four, 2-1. Billionaire Elon Musk just launched a Tesla Roadster into space with an astronaut mannequin in the driver's seat because he can do literally whatever he wants.

The roadster has now gone off track and is headed for the asteroid belt. But what was its original destination? Ed Henry?

HENRY: Mars, the orbit around Mars.

CARLSON: Mars. The orbit around Mars. All right. Let's check the tape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And just for fun. The payload on this test flight was a brand new electric Tesla Roadster, which is now heading to the Mars orbit. Starman astronaut dummy in the driver's seat with three cameras to provide epic views.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: That is correct. And by the way, our judges said they admired the precision with which you answered it. The Mars or the orbit around.

SHIMKUS: Casting a wide net.

CARLSON: So, this is the third week in a row that Carley has come to sudden death situation. Two-to=two. Winner of this takes the award, which has changed this week.

All right. Final question. Another example of tech changing everything. Best Buy, the company, announced this week that they would no longer be selling which music-related product?

SHIMKUS: Oh.

CARLSON: Ed Henry.

HENRY: CDs.

CARLSON: Boy, that's pretty authoritative.

SHIMKUS: That would make sense.

HENRY: It's not 8 tracks.

CARLSON: Let's check the tape. CDs.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: According to a report in "Billboard", Best Buy has just told music suppliers that it will pull CDs from its stores come July 1st.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Wow! And there you go. Carley Shimkus.

SHIMKUS: Let him have it. Such a nice guy.

CARLSON: If you are going to lose to someone, it should be Ed.

SHIMKUS: Absolutely.

CARLSON: All right, Ed. One era ends, another begins. We have a new prize. This is the Erik Wemple mug. This has a picture of Erik Wemple of "The Washington Post" guest on the show at one point. Here is what happened to him and then the back side is my triumphant face. The official Erik Wemple mug.

This is the very first day of it. Congratulations.

HENRY: Thank you. I will drink this with honor.

CARLSON: Thank you both. That was great.

Pay attention all week. "Final Exam" is over now, but next week we'll be back and you can see if you can outwit our contestants. We will return in just a moment.

CARLSON: Two big stories breaking tonight. The FBI spent more than 100 grand of tax dollars chasing damaging information on Donald Trump. Instead simply handed money to a Russian scammer for what looks like fraudulent information. What?

Also, President Trump says he is willing to release that committee memo, the Democratic one, but he's going to work with the intel committee on alterations to it.

Here is something new. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is planning a series of votes on immigration next week. Rather than pushing a specific bill, he's planning to let every proposal offered get up or down vote. We'll be on it next week and we'll tell you how your lawmakers voted on that issue.

Have a great weekend. See you Monday.

urn:contentItem:5TXB-5PC1-DY0W-4541-00000-00Tucker says ruling class clamps down on free speech; Big tech silences dissenting opinions, says Tucker Carlson; New York State legislature's new bill would require social media checks for prospective gun owners; Robert Mueller recommended no jail time for Mike Flynn; Census shows almost a fifth of Californians living in poverty; Low-skilled immigration overwhelmed California, says Tucker; Former President, George H.W. Bush, honored with state funeral at the Washington National Cathedral; Climate change is the great global environmental crisis that we face, says Bernie Sanders; Comedian Nimesh Patel booted off stage for offensive jokes during Columbia University performance; Democrats retook the House in November's midterm elections. Aired 8-9pm ET2018-12-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisTucker says ruling class clamps down on free speech; Big tech silences dissenting opinions, says Tucker Carlson; New York State legislature's new bill would require social media checks for prospective gun owners; Robert Mueller recommended no jail time for Mike Flynn; Census shows almost a fifth of Californians living in poverty; Low-skilled immigration overwhelmed California, says Tucker; Former President, George H.W. Bush, honored with state funeral at the Washington National Cathedral; Climate change is the great global environmental crisis that we face, says Bernie Sanders; Comedian Nimesh Patel booted off stage for offensive jokes during Columbia University performance; Democrats retook the House in November's midterm elections. Aired 8-9pm ETLanhamFULL TEXT

TUCKER CARLSON- HOST: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT. The Mueller investigation appears to be moving in directions that nobody could have anticipated, none of them obviously connected to Russian meddling in the past presidential election.

So, what is the point of all of this? And when and where does it end, if ever? Ken Starr and Joe diGenova join us in a moment on that.

But first tonight, freedom of speech. Lot of people voted for Donald Trump in the hope that they would have more of it. But two years in, the opposite has happened. A ruling class has clamped down, as never before, on personal expression.

Gone is the free exchange of ideas we were promised. As Americans, it was supposed to be our birthright, remember? But in its place now, mandatory soul-deadening conformity, an entire population forced to repeat the same mindless platitudes, or else.

An axis of Left-wing corporate power, academia, the media and lawmakers have all aligned to curb your right to speak freely, which is to say your right to think for yourself. When they control your words, they control your mind.

The Left used to deny that that was their goal. They're not pretending anymore. They're baring their teeth and snarling. Get in line or we'll hurt you.

In a speech on Monday night, CEO Tim Cook pledged that Apple, one of the biggest and most powerful companies in the history of the world, will do whatever it takes to silence dissenting opinion.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIMOTHY DONALD COOK, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, APPLE: Hate tries to make its headquarters in the digital world. At Apple, we believe that technology needs to have a clear point of view on this challenge. There is no time to get tied up in knots. That's why we only have one message for those who seek to push hate, division, and violence, you have no place on our platforms.

(CROWD CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Hate, it's a real thing. There's a lot of it out there right now. But hate is also the word they use for views they don't like or questions they can't answer.

Cook's real message is simple. We are holy. You are fallen. Shut up and obey. CEOs didn't used to talk like this. They were in the business of selling products, not preaching sermons.

Then, over time, conventional religion receded from public life, and people like Tim Cook and his fellow CEOs stepped forward to fill that void. It was not an upgrade. Apple has a lot more power than the Episcopal Church ever had, and much less humility, and much less restraint.

Leaders a 100 years ago could tolerate dissent. They thought God would sort it out in the end. They didn't have to. Members of our modern ruling class consider themselves God. They render their own judgment. They view disagreement as equivalent to apostasy, an attack on the one true faith.

In New York, to name but one example, among many, a new bill in the state legislature would ban anyone who says something politicians don't like from buying a firearm.

Prospective gun owners will be required to give up their passwords and to show their social media accounts to regulators who would inspect them for unapproved thoughts. Sound like something that Chinese military thought up? Yes, it does.

But Democrats are not apologizing for it. Listen to one of the sponsors of the bill explain.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN PARKER, NEW YORK STATE SENATOR, DEMOCRATIC MEMBER: If we make this law and you have to, you know, allow the - you know, the state government to, in fact, look at your social media posts, you can decide on whether you want a pistol license or not. You don't have to have a pistol license.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: That's true. You don't. You don't have to vote either or go to church of your choice or be tried by a jury of your peers. What other constitutional rights will soon be contingent on saying the right things?

To find out, we've invited Kevin Parker on the show tonight. He is the New York State Senator from Brooklyn, you just saw on that tape. Senator Parker, welcome. Thanks for coming on tonight.

PARKER: Thanks for having me on, Tucker.

CARLSON: So, I should just say at the outset what I'm sure of you (ph) as already know, which is it's already against federal law to sell firearms to the mentally ill, thank heaven, and I think all of us support that restriction. So, it's already against the law.

But what other constitutional rights that we, as Americans, possess should be contingent on how we behave on social media?

PARKER: Well, let's be clear. I take an oath that supports the amendments and - and the whole Constitution, both the U.S. and the--

CARLSON: Right.

PARKER: --the state government Constitution. And so, this is really not about impinging on constitutional rights. This is really about safety. This is really about how do we, in fact, make the State of New York as safe as possible.

CARLSON: Right.

PARKER: Now, we've already been very safe. We're one of the - the top three safest states in the entire country, particularly when you look at, you know, - you know, mass shootings, thank God.

But we can always be safer, and we can always make sure that what happened in Pittsburgh, what we saw in Parkland, what we saw in Orlando doesn't happen here.

And so, this - this law simply says let's look at, you know, what people are putting out on social media as a, you know, the - you know, part of a - a set of criteria that we're using to determine who gets handguns--

CARLSON: OK.

PARKER: --because what we've--

CARLSON: Well but then - but - but - but hold on, but - but--

PARKER: --what we've--

CARLSON: --and, by the way, I agree with your desire to make your state and - and every state as safe as - as we possibly can. But why restrict it to gun owners?

I mean you are an elected official. You are a State Senator. You wield a lot of power. You control people's lives. Why shouldn't I have the password to your social media accounts, so we can assess whether you should be wielding the power that you do?

CARLSON: Well, for more than a century, California represented everything that was great about America. In 1849, thousands rode wagons across the entire continent to participate in the Gold Rush. In the early 1900s, film directors came by the dozens from the East Coast and made Los Angeles the center of global film production.

During the Dust Bowl, thousands of Midwestern farmers found refuge in the Central Valley. And, of course, for decades, California has been home to the world's greatest technological innovation.

It's no accident that California became the country's richest state. It was a land of limitless opportunity. Even if you never made millions there, you could live in what was, in effect, a middle-class paradise.

That's not true anymore. According to the census, almost a fifth of Californians now live in poverty. That's the highest percentage in the country. California's middle-class is fleeing to Phoenix and Reno and Boise. Soon, the state will be comprised almost entirely of rich and poor.

How did this happen? That question is rarely asked. The answer is pretty simple. Low-skilled immigration overwhelmed California. More than a quarter of the state's entire population, as of today, is foreign-born. Again, the highest rate in the country.

Some of these immigrants are building successful new companies in Silicon Valley, good for them. But most of them are not. In fact, the overwhelming majority of these immigrants are on welfare.

Fully 72 percent of non-citizen households in the State of California now receive aid. That compares to just 35 percent of native-born households, more than double the rate. Now, a 100 years ago, immigrants came to California for opportunity. And now, they come for the benefits. Who can blame them?

Democrats long ago discovered that welfare is a handy vote-buying scheme. Free stuff equals political power. So, they give more even as native-born Californians are forced to flee an increasingly unaffordable state. Democratic lawmakers, even now, are considering a new bill that would give state-funded health insurance to adult illegal immigrants.

That means that literally anybody from anywhere on the globe could hop the border in Tijuana and get healthcare paid for by California taxpayers. Pretty generous. If only California cared about its own people this much, it would still be the Golden State.

Well, President George H.W. Bush was honored today in a state funeral at the Washington National Cathedral. It was a moving tribute to the country's 41st President. Here's some of the highlights from it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
