Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WK3-0731-JBHT-D128-00000-00Tucker: Voters are not impressed with the Russia story; Can Republican plan stop Mueller probe?; Who was spying on Trump campaign?; FBI investigators detain and question Trump campaign ally; Pat Davis Campaign Ad: 'F--- the NRA'; Pennsylvania Democrat runs on Trump's message; Democrats floundering without a message; South Africa's brutal farm murders; Daycare dollars for Somali terrorists; New Facebook plan to promote and suppress news2018-05-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisTucker: Voters are not impressed with the Russia story; Can Republican plan stop Mueller probe?; Who was spying on Trump campaign?; FBI investigators detain and question Trump campaign ally; Pat Davis Campaign Ad: 'F--- the NRA'; Pennsylvania Democrat runs on Trump's message; Democrats floundering without a message; South Africa's brutal farm murders; Daycare dollars for Somali terrorists; New Facebook plan to promote and suppress newsLanhamFULL TEXT

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST, TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT.

It is this week, the year anniversary of the beginning of the Robert Mueller Russia investigation. And at the end of that period, we have discovered there is still no evidence at all of collusion between the Donald Trump for President campaign of 2016 and the Russian government.

But Mueller's many supporters in Washington don't seem to care about that. That's because the investigation was never about Russia, obviously. The whole absurd fever dream was always a way for the ruling class to feel better about losing power in 2016.

It was a way for them to avoid thinking about why Trump got elected. And they never have thought about it.

Along the way, the investigation has provided Democrats with a full year of government-funded oppo research and destroyed the lives of a number of people who supported Donald Trump. There are added bonuses from the Democratic perspective.

But there have been downsides for Democrats. Voters are not impressed by the Russia story. It is weird and false and confusing. It has precisely nothing to do with voters' actual lives or the issues they vote on. It is a total waste of time for everyone.

And yet, it's all Democrats have. Trump is evil, so is Russia. That's the entire progressive program of 2018 summarized in two sentences. If the Democratic Party had a Sermon on the Mount, those would be the attitudes. No wonder their approval numbers are falling.

Republican Congressman Todd Rokita of Indiana has introduced a resolution calling for an end to Mueller's investigation or a report within 30 days. He joins us along with fellow Republican Ron DeSantis of Florida. He says he may know the identity of the person who was spied on Trump's campaign for the FBI in 2016.

Gentlemen, welcome to you both tonight. Congressman Rokita, first to you, so this resolution would call for an end to the investigation or a report summarizing its findings so far. Am I misstating that?

REP. TODD ROKITA (R), INDIANA: No. Both correct, Tucker. The fact of the matter is it's been a year. As you say, it's been $20 million and we need to see a report of what evidence he has. And absent that evidence, it should wind up within 30 days of the resolution passing.

CARLSON: So, why wouldn't other members on both sides in the Congress want some oversight? You are constitutionally bound to provide oversight of the DOJ. So, why are you the only person calling for this?

ROKITA: Well, I'm not. Matt Gaetz is also calling for it. There's a couple other calling for it, but we need your viewers to call your members of Congress and get them on board. You can only have a free republic, as you know, Tucker, if you have transparency. And this is exactly what we need.

It is a witch hunt. It has gone beyond an investigation. And the only evidence of collusion that we found, the only evidence of criminality has been on the Democrats.

So, we're calling on Mueller to show his hand or fold the deck.

CARLSON: Even if I believed the president colluded with Vladimir Putin, I'd be very concerned about this investigation because the parameters aren't clear. The timeline is opaque. And it's not clear what the point is.

So, Congressman DeSantis, one of the enduring mysteries of the past two weeks has been the story of a mole or a spy within the Trump campaign feeding information to the Russia investigation.

Have you any sense who that person might be?

REP. RON DESANTIS (R), FLORIDA: Look, I do, Tucker. But I think that the issue needs to go through the proper channels. I'm not comfortable disclosing who I think it is based on the evidence that I have.

But I can say this, the American people deserve an answer. Up or down, did the FBI direct somebody to spy on Donald Trump's campaign? Was somebody actively working to undermine his campaign and create the illusion of collusion?

And if that's the case, I think that's more serious than the FISA abuse. I think it's more serious than Rosenstein butchering this whole appointing order with Mueller from the beginning.

So, we need the answer to those questions. They are not giving us the answers right now, Tucker.

CARLSON: They are definitely not. Now, I know you don't want to risk libel by naming someone because this has not been proved in court, but give us a sense of what you are talking about. Are you saying that someone who worked on the Trump campaign fed information to law enforcement?

DESANTIS: So, if you look at Glenn Simpson's testimony from Fusion GPS, he talked about there being a human source. And that was something that was controversial. Some people said it was Papadopoulos. That's not what he was referring to.

So, the issue is he acknowledges there's a human source. Peter Strzok, he opens up the counterintelligence investigation in the summer of 2016, what does he do the next day? He goes to Great Britain, he goes to London and he's meeting with people.

Well, how the heck would you do that if you just opened the investigation that day? So, I think in that kind of - the London, Christopher Steele, Glenn Simpson axis is probably the individual that we're looking at.

But, I mean, look, we need to know whether this individual was spying or not. I have great concerns about it, but I think we can get those questions' answer when the Justice Department ponies up the documents.

CARLSON: So, last - you're absolutely right. The last follow-up on that, are you suggesting or do you believe that this is someone who was pressured into cooperating with the investigation or someone who freely sent information over about the campaign?

DESANTIS: I think it's the latter, Tucker. I think this would be somebody - potentially could have been paid by the FBI, like Steele. There was an agreement to pay Steele.

We just need an answer to that? Did they pay anybody? Yes or no. Did they direct anyone to go to the campaign? Yes or no. Very easy questions to answer.

ROKITA: And, Tucker, we need the -

CARLSON: Exactly. I'm sorry, congressman. Please go ahead.

ROKITA: Yes. Ron DeSantis is exactly right. We also need to know the relationship between Mueller and Comey. Comey kicked this whole thing off with a bogus FISA warrant. And what is the relationship between Mueller and Comey? Did Mueller give Comey immunity? Does Comey think he's about the law? Where are we going with all this? That what needs to be investigated.

CARLSON: Do believe - quickly, congressman, do you believe that Jim Comey has been offered immunity by the Mueller investigation?

ROKITA: I think it stands to reason. And I think the American people deserve to know.

CARLSON: That would be shocking. Congressmen, thank you both. I appreciate that. And I hope you get to the bottom of those. We have a right to know.

ROKITA: Thanks.

DESANTIS: Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: Ted Malloch was an informal advisor to the Donald Trump campaign. In March, he says he was detained at an airport by investigators for Robert Mueller who took away his cell phone and asked about his ties to Roger Stone, among other things. He is also the author of the book, "The Plot to Destroy Trump: How the Deep State Fabricated the Russian Dossier to Subvert the President".

Ted Malloch joins us tonight. Ted, thank you for coming on.

TED MALLOCH, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN ADVISER: Good evening.

CARLSON: When you say you were detained, that's kind of a remarkable story. Tell us the circumstances of this.

MALLOCH: Especially for a Yale, Oxford and a business school professor to be stopped at an airport, taken into a room and asked questions by the FBI and having their phone then under a warrant seized.

But I write about this in the book as a postscript and my lawyers tell me not to confirm or deny very much about this because I'm still actively participating in this conversation.

CARLSON: I don't understand. Why would that put you in legal peril if you believe the government overstepped and detained you - this is at Logan Airport in Boston, right? You're flying in from abroad. They pull you aside, take your cell phone and ask you questions. You have no lawyer present, is that correct, during this conversation?

MALLOCH: None at all.

CARLSON: OK. So, how - why would you be in jeopardy by exercising your First Amendment right to explain the truth?

MALLOCH: I have explained it as a postscript to the book and actually detailed it. And I'm told that the FBI is not all that happy about that fact. So, therefore, I'm not really at liberty to say a whole lot more about where this stands at present.

CARLSON: Right. Give us a sense, though. When you sat down, you had no lawyer. It's generally not advised to talk to the FBI without a lawyer. Did they just grab you as you got off the plane? And what did you say to them when they did?

MALLOCH: Well, they had me wait for about 20 minutes, as I say, and then divided me from my wife and then searched my belongings and took me to a separate building to introduce me to two FBI agents who asked me a series of questions.

Actually, it was quite chit chatty for about 20 minutes. As a fan of the Philadelphia Eagles, they asked me what I thought of their victory at the Super Bowl.

CARLSON: That's what they said to Mike Flynn too during his chit chatty conversation, I'm sure.

So, they had a warrant for all of this, I assume. Is that right?

MALLOCH: Correct.

CARLSON: OK. What did they ask you?

MALLOCH: As I said in the postscript, there were very few substantive questions. Some about individuals, what my relationship was to the campaign. They seem to know all the answers to the questions.

CARLSON: Did you consider saying buzz off, I'm not going to answer your questions?

MALLOCH: I think had they gotten any more aggressive, then, in fact, that would have been the case, but they were fairly benign. I'm a patriotic American. A cold warrior. I worked in the State Department. I was the top American in the UN in Geneva, Switzerland for four years at the end of the Cold War.

I'm certainly willing to cooperate in any inquiry. I don't think I have much to add.

CARLSON: Why do you think they wanted to talk to you?

MALLOCH: Well, my publisher thinks they had pre-read my book on the plot to destroy the president, which is, in fact, about the conspiracy - the first in American history since 1783 and the Newburgh conspiracy that tried to overthrow a sitting president of the United States.

CARLSON: Why did they ask you about Roger Stone?

MALLOCH: I have no idea. I've met Roger Stone three times. He did write the foreword to my new book because we had the same publisher. He gave an address at Oxford University about 8 or 10 weeks ago and it was a pretty compelling story about what happened in the 2016 election and we had it transcribed. I had attended that lecture. And we used it as the foreword to the book. So, maybe they read more into that than is the case.

CARLSON: What did they do to your phone? You said they had a warrant for your phone?

MALLOCH: Yes. They confiscated my phone and I'm told it's been returned to me and I should be receiving it any day.

CARLSON: They took your phone away? How long have they had it?

MALLOCH: Well, since that day, which was before Easter.

CARLSON: I'd be pretty annoyed. Ted, thank you for joining us. I appreciate it.

MALLOCH: Good to be with you, Tucker. Thanks.

CARLSON: Democratic congressional candidate has expressed his real thoughts about the NRA in a new ad, which is completely over-the-top. He joins us next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Well, a politician's job is to appeal to voters. Left-leaning voters don't like the NRA. Pat Davis is a Democrat running for Congress in New Mexico. Put two and two together and Davis has produced a new ad where he expresses his view of the NRA unambiguously, but you decide.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PAT DAVIS (D), NEW MEXICO CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: (EXPLETIVE DELETED) the NRA. Their program policies have resulted in dead children, dead mothers and dead fathers. I'm Pat Davis and I approve this message because if Congress won't change our gun laws, we are changing Congress.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Pat Davis joins us tonight from New Mexico. Pat, thanks for coming on.

DAVIS: Hi, Tucker.

CARLSON: So, that's the ad? Eff the NRA? Kind of moronic, no?

DAVIS: That's it, just 15 seconds, but it got a whole lot of attention and started a new conversation about guns and I'm grateful for that.

CARLSON: But doesn't it degrade you? You use the F word in an ad. I mean, if you have a position, state it, but F the NRA? I mean, come on.

DAVIS: Well, Tucker, being polite, it hasn't made our schools any safer, it hasn't protected police officers like I used to be. If a cuss word on TV offends you more than pictures of dead children in Parkland or Newtown, then your priorities are all wrong.

CARLSON: It's not either/or. I don't care if you were a cop or not. Hold on. Wait. Let me ask you a question. It's not an either/or. It's not that I'm so offended. Politeness doesn't work, do you think rudeness will? Is rudeness going to save lives, do you think?

DAVIS: As we were looking to make this ad, we kept coming up with the same idea. And every ad idea we came up to talk about this issue looked like somebody else's. And those had not worked.

Clearly, this got the NRA's attention and it has started a new conversation both amongst candidates running for office, about how we organize and take back Congress and put new leaders there to take on control, but also how we stand up to the NRA.

We know what works. Fifty percent of NRA members support -

CARLSON: No, it started a conversation about how embarrassing you are. How many NRA members have committed mass shootings?

DAVIS: Well - but, Tucker, here's the thing. A majority of Americans - 89 percent of police officers, a majority of NRA members know there are common sense things we can do.

CARLSON: Hold on. Slow down. You just released an ad that said F the NRA, which I'm sure back at your fraternity house they love. But let me ask you an adult question, how many NRA members have committed mass shootings?

DAVIS: Tucker, this is about the organization itself. My family grew up, when I was growing up -

CARLSON: I'm asking you about the organization itself.

DAVIS: It's not the NRA of my dad's organization.

CARLSON: F the NRA. But how many of their members - hold on. They have millions of members. How many of them -

DAVIS: They do. And I've been hearing from them all week. I've been hearing from them all week because the NRA made us their target.

We've started a new conversation and what I've also heard from are parents in Parkland, in Virginia, in Newtown who donated to keep the ad on the air because they want people in Congress to finally step up.

CARLSON: Right. So, you're really doing a public service.

DAVIS: If the NRA wants to come to the table and help us pass common sense regulations that their members support, let's do it.

CARLSON: Come to the table? You just said F the NRA.

DAVIS: We are not waiting on them to come to the table.

CARLSON: You're really trying to have an adult conversation. So, here is your new spot. And I want to talk to policy and see what you know about it. So, here's your latest 15-second ad.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAVIS: By the time this ad is done, an AR-15 could have fired 150 bullets. That's why we need to ban assault weapons. I'm Pat Davis, running for Congress. And I approve this message because lives are more important than gun company profits.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: So, you just said that in 15 seconds an AR-15 can fire 150 rounds. Is that true?

DAVIS: That's right. You get it right here in New Mexico. Right here in New Mexico, you can go to a parking lot or go on the Internet, buy an assault weapon, an AR-15 and buy a legally available add-on like a bump stock that allows you to replicate exactly what happened in Las Vegas.

The Las Vegas shooter could shoot 600 rounds a minute.

CARLSON: You are saying an AR-15 can shoot 150 rounds in 15 seconds. So, would it have a 150-round magazine? What would that - let me ask - let's be specific about your ad. What would that magazine look like, the 150- round magazine?

DAVIS: Exactly like the magazines the Las Vegas police officers pulled out of that hotel room. They had 50 and 100-round magazines and that weapon was capable -

CARLSON: So, you could fire - it is physically possible to fire - it's not. I mean, these are rhetorical questions. You don't know what you're talking about. I know that you are a police officer. Or you claim to have been.

DAVIS: Yes.

CARLSON: No AR-15 can fire 150 rounds in 15 seconds. That's untrue. And if you believe it is true, then you are not qualified to have a conversation about guns. People are laughing at you because you are ignorant. You don't know what you're talking about. No, no, that's just untrue.

DAVIS: We take exactly the word of the police officers in Las Vegas who I trust who ran into that room to save people down below and found a weapon that was modified with bump stocks.

CARLSON: Oh, so they say an AR-15 - what do you think would happen to the barrel in 15 seconds if you put 150 rounds? It would melt.

DAVIS: I know they get hot.

CARLSON: So, my point is if you're going to take on the NRA and be Mr. Tough, I was a cop guy, maybe you should know what you're talking about, but you don't.

You are putting something on television that's demonstrably wrong, that's physically possible, and all of your voters are like, oh, yes, this guy knows what he's talking about, he was a cop, but you don't know. So, maybe you should apologize for it.

DAVIS: I'm not apologizing for taking on the NRA. I know why I'm pursuing it.

CARLSON: I'm sorry. Politeness doesn't work. I'm just trying to - oh, OK.

I think you should apologize for saying something that's factually untrue.

DAVIS: Apologies and politeness have not changed the conversation. We need new focus to take over and decide.

CARLSON: Yes, that's why I'm not being polite. I'm trying to get a real conversation going here. But you don't know what you're talking about, so maybe you shouldn't be in a position to make decisions because you don't understand the issue because you just told me with a straight face that an AR-15 can fire 150 rounds in 15 seconds. Oh, surprise. It can't.

So, maybe you should admit that and move on to something you understand. Would you do that?

DAVIS: This is exactly the type of arguments that don't get us where we need to be. We need new leadership in Congress.

CARLSON: Oh, it's not like, F the NRA. That's the kind of argument we need. I thought politeness didn't work, tough guy?

DAVIS: Politeness is not working so far. If you woke up on Mother's Day and you don't have your kid anymore -

CARLSON: You know what works actually? Facts work. Why don't you get some facts? Oh, Pat, do you like this new mode of communication we have? F the NRA, Pat.

DAVIS: It would be great to have a conversation.

CARLSON: Learn something about funs and get back to me. Interview over. Yes, because you don't know what you are talking about.

Let's go back to politeness. I like it better. It's another primary night and a Democrat who sounds like Donald Trump could be a winner tonight. Amazing! He will join us.

Plus, Brit Hume joins us to break down the Democrats' 2018 message or lack thereof. Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: This is a Fox News alert. Primary elections held tonight in the State of Pennsylvania, polling places just closed. A court there has radically reshaped the state's congressional boundaries.

John Morganelli is a Democrat running for Congress in the newly reshaped 7th district in the state's northeast. The district only narrowly supported Hillary Clinton in 2016.

And despite his party affiliation, Morganelli is anti-abortion and has called for some restrictions on immigration and sanctuary cities. Mr. Morganelli joins us tonight. Mr. Morganelli, thanks a lot for coming on.

JOHN MORGANELLI, PENNSYLVANIA CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: Tucker, thanks for having me tonight.

CARLSON: So, as I understand, there are three candidates, Democratic candidates, running in this primary tonight. Polls have closed. So, we are not affecting anything with his interview.

But the three candidates each come from a different strain of the Democratic Party ideologically. Describe the kind of Democrat that you are.

MORGANELLI: Well, Tucker, I've come out of a blue-collar background. My father was a construction worker with a sixth-grade education. My mother was a seamstress with 11th grade education.

And I believe that I've come out of the sort of the traditional Democratic Party that's concerned about working men and women, that's concerned about the blue-collar issues that affect these folks and I have always believed the John F. Kennedy model and, even to some degree, the Bill Clinton model, who ran as a centrist. And that's pretty much where I have been. I'm not the strain of Democratic Party.

CARLSON: So, I'm fascinated by the news coverage of your race. So, you've said things that don't seem very controversial, like you are not in favor of giving driver's licenses to illegal immigrants. You are not against all immigration, but you're worried about illegal immigration. And you're not for giving state-subsidized tuition to illegal immigrants.

For this, you are described as a hard-liner on immigration. Do you think that's fair? Do you think the coverage of that subject is fair?

MORGANELLI: No, I don't think it's fair. First of all, I'm a grandson of an Italian immigrant and I believe immigration is great. It's made our country great.

But immigration is a process. There is laws that we have and people have to get in line and come into the country in a legal way. And to describe me as a hard-liner, I think, is not accurate.

I go to the naturalization service that we have in our county where people from all over the world become naturalized citizens. It's a wonderful ceremony in the courthouse. And those are immigrants.

What I'm opposed to is just people breaking into our country without permission. Some of them being criminals, and I've seen them in my own county from the MS-13 gang and others.

CARLSON: Yes.

MORGANELLI: And then, our country giving incentives for more illegal immigration such as driver's license and state tuition, I don't think those incentives should be given. It just creates more illegal immigration.

CARLSON: So, Bill Clinton said that exact same thing 20 years ago. Now, you are one of only a couple Democrats willing to say that out loud. What happened to the Democratic Party?

MORGANELLI: Well, it's interesting. As you know, there is a picture - a video of President Clinton giving, I think, a State of the Union speech where he talks hard-line on immigration. He says everything that I believe in. And even President Obama gave a similar speech. So, this is not out of step with Democrats.

I mean, in my own community here, I have great support for this position. People here, Democratic voters, I don't think - I guess we'll know better tonight - want foreign criminals coming into the county and setting up shop.

They don't want sanctuary cities. I have opposed sanctuary cities for a long, long time. Having a sanctuary city is like putting up a big sign that says, please, all foreign criminals, come here because we won't do anything about it if you commit a crime.

CARLSON: Exactly.

MORGANELLI: So, I don't think that all Democrats are in lockstep necessarily with some of the national philosophy that comes out of Washington on this issue.

CARLSON: Man, I hope you are right. And the polls have closed, so I can say that I'm certainly rooting for you tonight. John Morganelli, thanks a lot for coming on.

MORGANELLI: Thank you. Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: Probably won't help. Well, with some candidates on the Democratic side flipping the bird to the NRA, while others back Trump-style immigration, it's not quite clear what the Democratic message is for 2018.

Brit Hume is Fox's senior political analyst. He watches carefully. He joins us tonight. Brit, what do you think the message is? Or is there a national message that the Democratic Party is selling this midterm?

BRIT HUME, FOX NEWS SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST: I think it's pretty indistinct at this moment, if there is one, Tucker. I think that much of the party is so mesmerized by Donald Trump and loathes him so deeply that that has become kind of the central thing and the central theme that you can see with the Democratic - that's what the Democratic Party appears to be mostly about right now. I suspect, as time goes on, something more oriented towards voters will come along.

But, remember, Tucker, these candidates are running in a party where 71 percent, according to one recent poll, want Donald Trump impeached. So, it's kind of understandable that there would be some focus on him.

CARLSON: Yes. For sure. Most Democrats are, of course, very anti-Trump. That's why they are Democrats. But is that a message that moves people to the polls?

HUME: Well, based on the evidence we have, it seems not to be working very well. And the reason I say that is, look at the advantages that Democrats enjoy going into this midterm election.

First of all, the political gravity in any president's first midterm is always with the other party and the average loss is more than would be enough - if they made their average again, the Democrats would get control of the House.

Now, they had a huge gap in what's called the generic ballot. You know, Tucker, that's the one where you ask people if they'd rather vote for a Democrat or Republican unnamed in the upcoming election.

Normally, Democrats do well on that ballot. They were up plus 15 or 16 at one point not very long ago. And now, that number is down to single digits. And some polls down to low single digits which suggest that whatever they are selling, people are not buying with the enthusiasm that the party had hoped for.

CARLSON: What will happen if they don't retake the House?

HUME: Well, I think there will be an agonizing reappraisal because we've been hearing about this blue wave that was thought to be inevitable, and may yet come.

If it doesn't come, obviously, there's going to be a search for scapegoats. And we will see what happens.

But this party, I think, Tucker, what we're seeing emerge now is that for all the divisions in the Republican Party between Trump supporters and the never Trumpers and so on and all the divisions within the conservative movement over that, the divisions in the Democratic Party are at least as deep, if not deeper.

And at the heart of the Democratic Party - I remember you saying in a speech not too many years ago - was not with Hillary Clinton, but she won anyway.

A candidate of her stripe, I don't think, could win this time. I don't know that a white male candidate could win.

So, here we are, the Democrats really have some serious divisions to worry about. And whether whatever they come up with will be appealing to a broad cross section of voters is, obviously, what remains to be seen.

CARLSON: A white male candidate could not win. I don't think a lot of the white male candidates running for the Democratic nomination know that yet, but I think they're going to learn.

And do you think that it moves in the direction of populist economics, become the Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders party?

HUME: Well, I think that's the drift. And I think that excites a lot of people. And, of course, if you look at the attitudes of young voters now, who do not seem to have grasped the benefits of a market capitalist economy and don't seem to be put off at all about the idea of socialism despite socialism's abysmal history, which is playing out even today in certain parts of the world, Venezuela being the most conspicuous example, but I think the party - it's gotten pretty far left now. And a lot of old ideas that are being passed off as kind of new ideas are in the air.

And the party will have to reckon with that because if they come up with somebody who is an out and out socialist for president, I don't think they could possibly win. And I'm not sure how many of them we'll see, but there will be awful battles over this.

CARLSON: Their corporate donors, because the party is entirely supported by corporate America, are going to pretty surprised when it turns out they're sending money to Hugo Chavez.

Brit Hume, thank you.

HUME: Yes. You bet, Tucker.

CARLSON: Sorry. Go ahead.

HUME: No, I was just going to say don't underestimate the ability of a leftist candidate to raise money from small donations and make a serious run for it. Bernie Sanders certainly did.

CARLSON: No, that's right. I just think that Goldman Sachs guys are going to be pretty shocked when they see what's coming. Great to see you.

HUME: Thank you, Tucker.

CARLSON: Well, an embattled minority group is under attack in South Africa and on the receiving end of genocidal rhetoric. It is considered unacceptable to talk about this in the media in the West for some reason, but we don't care because it's true and it's happening and it's news and we are covering it. That's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Well, now to a fascinating and significant story the media have all but ignored. South Africa is a diverse country, but the South African government would like to make it much less diverse.

An embattled minority of farmers, mostly Afrikaans speaking, is being targeted in a wave of barbaric and horrifying murders.

But instead of protecting them, the government just passed a law allowing it to seize their farms without any compensation based purely on their ethnicity and distribute those farms to more favored groups.

Thousands have already migrated out of the country, but they've struggled to attract any sympathy abroad for some reason.

Ernst Roets is deputy CEO of AfriForum. It's a South Africa civil rights group. He was just in the United States to meet with a number of government officials. He also took a moment to talk to us. Here's part of what he said.

Ernst Roets joins us now. Mr. Roets, thanks for coming on.

ERNST ROETS, SOUTH AFRICAN CIVIL RIGHTS ACTIVIST: Thank you very much.

CARLSON: So, you describe in this book a disorganized, but in some sense intentional campaign to crush a racial minority within your country and the government seems onboard with it. Is that an overstatement?

ROETS: Well, what the book is about is it's about government complicity in the scourge of farm attacks and farm murders that we've seen in South Africa.

So, in only the last two decades, there's been - according to government statistics, which we believe - we have reason to say that it's maybe downplayed a little. There's been about two farm attacks every day and two farm murders every week in South Africa.

And in the book, I highlight actually ten different reasons why we believe the South African government is complicit. And it stretches from reasons including - the fact that as these attacks have worsened - for example, in 2007, there was a 25 percent increase in these attacks and then the South African government responded saying we're not going to release any more statistics about this.

Then also, which is very concerning, is the hate speech in South Africa. That's the title of the book as well, "Kill the Boer", which is a very popular song which is still being sung in South Africa. It was sung just the other day. So, it's sung at political rallies.

And, of course, Boer referring to a particular cultural group in South Africa.

CARLSON: Right.

ROETS: We have songs like "Shoot the Boer", which is a different song. There are a variety of ways in which -

CARLSON: But I thought that hate speech was now a crime punishable by prison time in South Africa. Are any of the people who say this arrested?

ROETS: There's a bill on the table to have hate speech declared a crime punishable by prison time. But if you look at the motivation around it, it's very clear that - I think those in government who are pushing this don't regard this as hate speech.

As a matter of fact, they've been arguing that it's not hate speech in court. So, they would argue that they have a right to sing about killing farmers and then they would say it's an expression of freedom of speech.

CARLSON: So, now the government has announced that it plans to pursue a policy of taking land away from people on the basis of their skin color. Do you think they'll do that?

ROETS: Well, that's what was adopted in our parliament in February. A motion was adopted that the property rights clause in the South African constitution has to be changed to allow for expropriation of private property without compensation.

So, the state president, Cyril Ramaphosa, said that this would turn South Africa into the ultimate paradise and the Garden of Eden and Deputy President David Mabuza even went further saying that - basically threatening white farmers that if they do not voluntarily hand over their land to black people, then there would be a violent takeover. So, the situation is very dire in South Africa.

But the good news is that there is still a process that has to be followed and that's why we are in the United States.

CARLSON: What I find so striking is the response from everyone else around the world. It's almost never covered in the American media. There is a sense that the people being murdered deserve it because of what their ancestors did. And the international community is similarly silent.

Have you met with any government officials here in Washington about what's happening in your country?

ROETS: Well, that's why we are here. We are about to meet with some government officials and it's very unfortunate, the situation that you've just mentioned.

Especially in South Africa, there's a hierarchy of recognition. So, some people, when they are the victims, it's all over the news and you hear about it frequently. And other people, especially farmers in South Africa, white farmers in particular, they would be tortured to death and it would receive very little news coverage.

And that's unfortunately the situation abroad as well, which is why we are very grateful to be having this.

CARLSON: So, a government official in Australia said publicly maybe we ought to allow asylum to people being persecuted for their skin color in your country and he was basically laughed at and then attacked by your government for saying that.

ROETS: Yes, he was attacked. And they then said that he shouldn't say that because AfriForum was providing them with false information. Well, the information that we're quoting is government statistics.

So, that is the situation. Whoever speaks out against this - we, just for being in the United States, we've been accused of treason, we've had people threatening us, saying they will wait for us at the airport when we come back and they'll attack us and so forth. We had the state president today in parliament calling on us to go back to South Africa.

So, whenever you speak out against this, there is a very serious backlash.

CARLSON: This is not what Nelson Mandela wanted.

ROETS: No, it's the exact opposite than what he wanted. He spoke about a free country in which people were not judged by the color of their skin. And he even wanted farm attacks to be a priority crime.

He said that when he was president. And when his presidency was over, they deprioritized it.

CARLSON: So, you just watch something like this happen in a neighboring country, Zimbabwe, which went from being one of the richest in Africa to the poorest in the world because of farm attacks and because of the theft of private property, is the ANC, the ruling party in South Africa, aware of that lesson?

ROETS: Well, they are, but you know that saying real communism has never been tried. That's what they keep saying. So, it failed in Zimbabwe. It failed in Cuba. It failed in Venezuela. It failed in Russia. It failed in China. All of those countries.

And they are basically saying that we're going to try the same thing, but this time it's going to work.

CARLSON: So, last question. It's considered basically immoral in the United States to talk to you or to hear stories like this for reasons that nobody ever bothers really to explain, but it's just understood.

If you could speak to our media, to the people who are dismissing your claims as false, what would you say?

ROETS: Well, I think there are three things. Firstly, everything we say is fact based. It's based on research. But in terms of what we hope to achieve and what people can do, people who want to invest in South Africa, we want them to call on the South African government to say, listen, you are calling on us to invest in your country, but you want to expropriate those investments.

Number two, we are speaking with the US government and asking them to put pressure on the South African government, which could be done in a variety of ways.

And number three, members of the public and members of the media, the best thing that you can do to help us is to talk about this, to talk about it on public platforms and in that way to continue to put pressure on the South African government not to continue with this policy.

CARLSON: Just to tell the truth. I agree. Mr. Roets, thank you.

ROETS: Thanks very much. Thank you for being here.

CARLSON: Tech companies are getting more powerful, even as we sleep. Facebook has a plan for ranking news outlets by how trustworthy it says they are, while Twitter plans to just censor certain views entirely. A brave new world has arrived. Details ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Millions of taxpayer dollars may have been used to fund terrorists in Somalia. That's according to a new report by a Fox affiliate in the twin cities.

According to that story, many members of Minnesota's Somali immigrant community have discovered they can open sham day care centers that only pretend to watch children, collect a fat subsidy from the state for doing that and keep the change. They have made millions of dollars, up to 100 million according to that report. That would be half of Minnesota's annual budget for child care assistance.

Again, these are people who are resettled here as an act of charity by our country, accused now of defrauding our country. And not just fraud, fraud so brazen, the report says, that Somalis buy shares in fake day care outlets to get a cut of it.

Some of this fraudulently obtained money is reportedly being shipped back to Somalia in suitcases full of cash to evade federal wire transfer restrictions.

Some of this money is ending up in regions of Somalia controlled by the Islamic terror group, Al-Shabab.

Well, Democratic Congressman Keith Ellison of Minnesota is outraged by the story. It's not the fraud that makes him mad or the ingratitude or the injustice. It was that it was exposed at all. That offended him.

In a statement, he denounced the new report on the grounds that it could hinder further cash transfers to Somalia, which apparently he cares more about than America, which he's supposed be representing.

According to Congressman Ellison, briefcases of untraceable cash in Somalia hurt Al-Shabab rather than helping them somehow.

Well, apparently, it's not enough for the tech companies to know what you do, and they do know what you do, increasingly they want to control what you do and what you see and what you think.

During a recent meeting with investors, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg revealed that his company has been ranking news outlets by how trustworthy they are, with less trusted outlets being penalized on Facebook's news feed. Trusted, by the way, by Facebook, not by you, but by Mark Zuckerberg and his deputies.

Meanwhile, Twitter is implementing a system to suppress tweets it regards as harassment, even if those tweets actually break no rules. In other words, if Twitter disagrees with the political orientation of the tweets.

Brett Larson hosts "Fox News Headlines 24/7" and investigates big tech for the show. We're grateful he does. He joins us tonight.

BRETT LARSON, FOX NEWS "FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7" HOST: Hey, Tucker. Good to be here. We have been investigating this story over the past few days now, involving Facebook changes to how they handle news sources in user's news feed.

As you mentioned, in a meeting with media company executives from "The New York Times" to News Corp., which is the parent company of Fox News, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said they will be relying on user surveys to determine which news sources are "broadly trusted." Now, the comments were made following Facebook's F8 Developer Conference. That was at the beginning of the month. And this is one of the many changes the social media giant has made in an effort to combat fake news, fake accounts and bots that help amplify and spread fake information.

Now, I spoke with Facebook earlier today and they assured me that this isn't an effort to censor any ideas or beliefs and that the random sampling of trustworthiness happens frequently to ensure sites are getting a fair shake.

It works like this. A user will be presented with a simple yes or no question about a news site. Are you familiar with the site? A "yes" answer brings up the next question to rate it for trustworthiness on a scale of 1 to 5.

Now, what about fake accounts boosting the trustworthiness of a not-so- trustworthy news outlet? Well, Facebook just this year has removed more than half a billion fake accounts.

Further, those headlines like "They pulled over to help this dog, what happened next will amaze you.", not going to get the kind of ranking in your news feed going forward as the changes are also meant to crackdown on so-called clickbait and focus more on news, especially local news.

Now, as for paying providers for that news, no deal. Cable operators pay to carry channels like Fox for their customers. But when asked if Facebook will do the same thing, the online giant saying, they don't see a need for that.

Despite the fact that they're renewing focus on local news, it would seem that kind of revenue would breathe life into local newspapers and news outlets that are struggling to remain relevant and profitable in the age of digital.

And, Tucker, these changes aren't helping us feel any better. In this effort to see more news from friends and less news from media sites, it actually puts us in a bad mood because we compare ourselves to our friends and our peers and we see what we are missing out on. Think parties and awesome vacations that we are not on. Tucker?

It's what we all want. We don't want to be informed, we want to feel bad!

CARLSON: Maybe we need a vacation from social media.

LARSON: I think we all do.

CARLSON: I think we do. Brett, great to see you.

LARSON: Thanks, Tucker. Good to be here.

CARLSON: Up next, the "Creepy Porn Lawyer" isn't just ruling the airwaves in other channels, he's also up to new antics online. We feel obligated to bring you the latest on that. Pretty amusing actually. Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Sad news tonight. The "Creepy Porn Lawyer" seems to be unstoppable. He's taken over the 2018 election cycle in two cable news networks. He'll be running for president himself before long.

But like other ominous entities like killer robots to Jeff Bezos, the "Creepy Porn Lawyer" needs energy to function and he gets that through attention and validation until today.

He posted a poll on Twitter asking whether he ought to keep going on TV or give people who aren't creepy porn lawyers a chance. Thousands have voted. Ninety three percent want him to keep gumming up the air waves. Doubtless his act of crass self-validation will keep "Creepy Porn Lawyer" fully operational for at least another 36 hours. Sad news!

And on that note, thanks for the hour. Sean Hannity is next from New York.

END

END

urn:contentItem:5WK3-0731-JBHT-D121-00000-00Tucker: Voters are not impressed with the Russia story; Can Republican plan stop Mueller probe?; Who was spying on Trump campaign?; FBI investigators detain and question Trump campaign ally; Pat Davis Campaign Ad: 'F--- the NRA'; Pennsylvania Democrat runs on Trump's message; Democrats floundering without a message; South Africa's brutal farm murders; Daycare dollars for Somali terrorists; New Facebook plan to promote and suppress news2018-05-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisTucker: Voters are not impressed with the Russia story; Can Republican plan stop Mueller probe?; Who was spying on Trump campaign?; FBI investigators detain and question Trump campaign ally; Pat Davis Campaign Ad: 'F--- the NRA'; Pennsylvania Democrat runs on Trump's message; Democrats floundering without a message; South Africa's brutal farm murders; Daycare dollars for Somali terrorists; New Facebook plan to promote and suppress newsLanhamFULL TEXT

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST, TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT.

It is this week, the year anniversary of the beginning of the Robert Mueller Russia investigation. And at the end of that period, we have discovered there is still no evidence at all of collusion between the Donald Trump for President campaign of 2016 and the Russian government.

But Mueller's many supporters in Washington don't seem to care about that. That's because the investigation was never about Russia, obviously. The whole absurd fever dream was always a way for the ruling class to feel better about losing power in 2016.

It was a way for them to avoid thinking about why Trump got elected. And they never have thought about it.

Along the way, the investigation has provided Democrats with a full year of government-funded oppo research and destroyed the lives of a number of people who supported Donald Trump. There are added bonuses from the Democratic perspective.

But there have been downsides for Democrats. Voters are not impressed by the Russia story. It is weird and false and confusing. It has precisely nothing to do with voters' actual lives or the issues they vote on. It is a total waste of time for everyone.

And yet, it's all Democrats have. Trump is evil, so is Russia. That's the entire progressive program of 2018 summarized in two sentences. If the Democratic Party had a Sermon on the Mount, those would be the attitudes. No wonder their approval numbers are falling.

Republican Congressman Todd Rokita of Indiana has introduced a resolution calling for an end to Mueller's investigation or a report within 30 days. He joins us along with fellow Republican Ron DeSantis of Florida. He says he may know the identity of the person who was spied on Trump's campaign for the FBI in 2016.

Gentlemen, welcome to you both tonight. Congressman Rokita, first to you, so this resolution would call for an end to the investigation or a report summarizing its findings so far. Am I misstating that?

REP. TODD ROKITA (R), INDIANA: No. Both correct, Tucker. The fact of the matter is it's been a year. As you say, it's been $20 million and we need to see a report of what evidence he has. And absent that evidence, it should wind up within 30 days of the resolution passing.

CARLSON: So, why wouldn't other members on both sides in the Congress want some oversight? You are constitutionally bound to provide oversight of the DOJ. So, why are you the only person calling for this?

ROKITA: Well, I'm not. Matt Gaetz is also calling for it. There's a couple other calling for it, but we need your viewers to call your members of Congress and get them on board. You can only have a free republic, as you know, Tucker, if you have transparency. And this is exactly what we need.

It is a witch hunt. It has gone beyond an investigation. And the only evidence of collusion that we found, the only evidence of criminality has been on the Democrats.

So, we're calling on Mueller to show his hand or fold the deck.

CARLSON: Even if I believed the president colluded with Vladimir Putin, I'd be very concerned about this investigation because the parameters aren't clear. The timeline is opaque. And it's not clear what the point is.

So, Congressman DeSantis, one of the enduring mysteries of the past two weeks has been the story of a mole or a spy within the Trump campaign feeding information to the Russia investigation.

Have you any sense who that person might be?

REP. RON DESANTIS (R), FLORIDA: Look, I do, Tucker. But I think that the issue needs to go through the proper channels. I'm not comfortable disclosing who I think it is based on the evidence that I have.

But I can say this, the American people deserve an answer. Up or down, did the FBI direct somebody to spy on Donald Trump's campaign? Was somebody actively working to undermine his campaign and create the illusion of collusion?

And if that's the case, I think that's more serious than the FISA abuse. I think it's more serious than Rosenstein butchering this whole appointing order with Mueller from the beginning.

So, we need the answer to those questions. They are not giving us the answers right now, Tucker.

CARLSON: They are definitely not. Now, I know you don't want to risk libel by naming someone because this has not been proved in court, but give us a sense of what you are talking about. Are you saying that someone who worked on the Trump campaign fed information to law enforcement?

DESANTIS: So, if you look at Glenn Simpson's testimony from Fusion GPS, he talked about there being a human source. And that was something that was controversial. Some people said it was Papadopoulos. That's not what he was referring to.

So, the issue is he acknowledges there's a human source. Peter Strzok, he opens up the counterintelligence investigation in the summer of 2016, what does he do the next day? He goes to Great Britain, he goes to London and he's meeting with people.

Well, how the heck would you do that if you just opened the investigation that day? So, I think in that kind of - the London, Christopher Steele, Glenn Simpson axis is probably the individual that we're looking at.

But, I mean, look, we need to know whether this individual was spying or not. I have great concerns about it, but I think we can get those questions' answer when the Justice Department ponies up the documents.

CARLSON: So, last - you're absolutely right. The last follow-up on that, are you suggesting or do you believe that this is someone who was pressured into cooperating with the investigation or someone who freely sent information over about the campaign?

DESANTIS: I think it's the latter, Tucker. I think this would be somebody - potentially could have been paid by the FBI, like Steele. There was an agreement to pay Steele.

We just need an answer to that? Did they pay anybody? Yes or no. Did they direct anyone to go to the campaign? Yes or no. Very easy questions to answer.

ROKITA: And, Tucker, we need the -

CARLSON: Exactly. I'm sorry, congressman. Please go ahead.

ROKITA: Yes. Ron DeSantis is exactly right. We also need to know the relationship between Mueller and Comey. Comey kicked this whole thing off with a bogus FISA warrant. And what is the relationship between Mueller and Comey? Did Mueller give Comey immunity? Does Comey think he's about the law? Where are we going with all this? That what needs to be investigated.

CARLSON: Do believe - quickly, congressman, do you believe that Jim Comey has been offered immunity by the Mueller investigation?

ROKITA: I think it stands to reason. And I think the American people deserve to know.

CARLSON: That would be shocking. Congressmen, thank you both. I appreciate that. And I hope you get to the bottom of those. We have a right to know.

ROKITA: Thanks.

DESANTIS: Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: Ted Malloch was an informal advisor to the Donald Trump campaign. In March, he says he was detained at an airport by investigators for Robert Mueller who took away his cell phone and asked about his ties to Roger Stone, among other things. He is also the author of the book, "The Plot to Destroy Trump: How the Deep State Fabricated the Russian Dossier to Subvert the President".

Ted Malloch joins us tonight. Ted, thank you for coming on.

TED MALLOCH, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN ADVISER: Good evening.

CARLSON: When you say you were detained, that's kind of a remarkable story. Tell us the circumstances of this.

MALLOCH: Especially for a Yale, Oxford and a business school professor to be stopped at an airport, taken into a room and asked questions by the FBI and having their phone then under a warrant seized.

But I write about this in the book as a postscript and my lawyers tell me not to confirm or deny very much about this because I'm still actively participating in this conversation.

CARLSON: I don't understand. Why would that put you in legal peril if you believe the government overstepped and detained you - this is at Logan Airport in Boston, right? You're flying in from abroad. They pull you aside, take your cell phone and ask you questions. You have no lawyer present, is that correct, during this conversation?

MALLOCH: None at all.

CARLSON: OK. So, how - why would you be in jeopardy by exercising your First Amendment right to explain the truth?

MALLOCH: I have explained it as a postscript to the book and actually detailed it. And I'm told that the FBI is not all that happy about that fact. So, therefore, I'm not really at liberty to say a whole lot more about where this stands at present.

CARLSON: Right. Give us a sense, though. When you sat down, you had no lawyer. It's generally not advised to talk to the FBI without a lawyer. Did they just grab you as you got off the plane? And what did you say to them when they did?

MALLOCH: Well, they had me wait for about 20 minutes, as I say, and then divided me from my wife and then searched my belongings and took me to a separate building to introduce me to two FBI agents who asked me a series of questions.

Actually, it was quite chit chatty for about 20 minutes. As a fan of the Philadelphia Eagles, they asked me what I thought of their victory at the Super Bowl.

CARLSON: That's what they said to Mike Flynn too during his chit chatty conversation, I'm sure.

So, they had a warrant for all of this, I assume. Is that right?

MALLOCH: Correct.

CARLSON: OK. What did they ask you?

MALLOCH: As I said in the postscript, there were very few substantive questions. Some about individuals, what my relationship was to the campaign. They seem to know all the answers to the questions.

CARLSON: Did you consider saying buzz off, I'm not going to answer your questions?

MALLOCH: I think had they gotten any more aggressive, then, in fact, that would have been the case, but they were fairly benign. I'm a patriotic American. A cold warrior. I worked in the State Department. I was the top American in the UN in Geneva, Switzerland for four years at the end of the Cold War.

I'm certainly willing to cooperate in any inquiry. I don't think I have much to add.

CARLSON: Why do you think they wanted to talk to you?

MALLOCH: Well, my publisher thinks they had pre-read my book on the plot to destroy the president, which is, in fact, about the conspiracy - the first in American history since 1783 and the Newburgh conspiracy that tried to overthrow a sitting president of the United States.

CARLSON: Why did they ask you about Roger Stone?

MALLOCH: I have no idea. I've met Roger Stone three times. He did write the foreword to my new book because we had the same publisher. He gave an address at Oxford University about 8 or 10 weeks ago and it was a pretty compelling story about what happened in the 2016 election and we had it transcribed. I had attended that lecture. And we used it as the foreword to the book. So, maybe they read more into that than is the case.

CARLSON: What did they do to your phone? You said they had a warrant for your phone?

MALLOCH: Yes. They confiscated my phone and I'm told it's been returned to me and I should be receiving it any day.

CARLSON: They took your phone away? How long have they had it?

MALLOCH: Well, since that day, which was before Easter.

CARLSON: I'd be pretty annoyed. Ted, thank you for joining us. I appreciate it.

HUME: Well, based on the evidence we have, it seems not to be working very well. And the reason I say that is, look at the advantages that Democrats enjoy going into this midterm election.

First of all, the political gravity in any president's first midterm is always with the other party and the average loss is more than would be enough - if they made their average again, the Democrats would get control of the House.

Now, they had a huge gap in what's called the generic ballot. You know, Tucker, that's the one where you ask people if they'd rather vote for a Democrat or Republican unnamed in the upcoming election.

Normally, Democrats do well on that ballot. They were up plus 15 or 16 at one point not very long ago. And now, that number is down to single digits. And some polls down to low single digits which suggest that whatever they are selling, people are not buying with the enthusiasm that the party had hoped for.

CARLSON: What will happen if they don't retake the House?

If it doesn't come, obviously, there's going to be a search for scapegoats. And we will see what happens.

But this party, I think, Tucker, what we're seeing emerge now is that for all the divisions in the Republican Party between Trump supporters and the never Trumpers and so on and all the divisions within the conservative movement over that, the divisions in the Democratic Party are at least as deep, if not deeper.

And at the heart of the Democratic Party - I remember you saying in a speech not too many years ago - was not with Hillary Clinton, but she won anyway.

A candidate of her stripe, I don't think, could win this time. I don't know that a white male candidate could win.

So, here we are, the Democrats really have some serious divisions to worry about. And whether whatever they come up with will be appealing to a broad cross section of voters is, obviously, what remains to be seen.

CARLSON: A white male candidate could not win. I don't think a lot of the white male candidates running for the Democratic nomination know that yet, but I think they're going to learn.

And a lot of old ideas that are being passed off as kind of new ideas are in the air.

And the party will have to reckon with that because if they come up with somebody who is an out and out socialist for president, I don't think they could possibly win. And I'm not sure how many of them we'll see, but there will be awful battles over this.

CARLSON: Well, now to a fascinating and significant story the media have all but ignored. South Africa is a diverse country, but the South African government would like to make it much less diverse.

An embattled minority of farmers, mostly Afrikaans speaking, is being targeted in a wave of barbaric and horrifying murders.

But instead of protecting them, the government just passed a law allowing it to seize their farms without any compensation based purely on their ethnicity and distribute those farms to more favored groups.

Thousands have already migrated out of the country, but they've struggled to attract any sympathy abroad for some reason.

Ernst Roets is deputy CEO of AfriForum. It's a South Africa civil rights group. He was just in the United States to meet with a number of government officials. He also took a moment to talk to us. Here's part of what he said.

Ernst Roets joins us now. Mr. Roets, thanks for coming on.

ERNST ROETS, SOUTH AFRICAN CIVIL RIGHTS ACTIVIST: Thank you very much.

CARLSON: So, you describe in this book a disorganized, but in some sense intentional campaign to crush a racial minority within your country and the government seems onboard with it. Is that an overstatement?

ROETS: Well, what the book is about is it's about government complicity in the scourge of farm attacks and farm murders that we've seen in South Africa.

So, in only the last two decades, there's been - according to government statistics, which we believe - we have reason to say that it's maybe downplayed a little. There's been about two farm attacks every day and two farm murders every week in South Africa.

And in the book, I highlight actually ten different reasons why we believe the South African government is complicit. And it stretches from reasons including - the fact that as these attacks have worsened - for example, in 2007, there was a 25 percent increase in these attacks and then the South African government responded saying we're not going to release any more statistics about this.

Then also, which is very concerning, is the hate speech in South Africa. That's the title of the book as well, "Kill the Boer", which is a very popular song which is still being sung in South Africa. It was sung just the other day. So, it's sung at political rallies.

And, of course, Boer referring to a particular cultural group in South Africa.

CARLSON: Right.

ROETS: We have songs like "Shoot the Boer", which is a different song. There are a variety of ways in which -

CARLSON: But I thought that hate speech was now a crime punishable by prison time in South Africa. Are any of the people who say this arrested?

ROETS: There's a bill on the table to have hate speech declared a crime punishable by prison time. But if you look at the motivation around it, it's very clear that - I think those in government who are pushing this don't regard this as hate speech.

As a matter of fact, they've been arguing that it's not hate speech in court. So, they would argue that they have a right to sing about killing farmers and then they would say it's an expression of freedom of speech.

CARLSON: So, now the government has announced that it plans to pursue a policy of taking land away from people on the basis of their skin color. Do you think they'll do that?

ROETS: Well, that's what was adopted in our parliament in February. A motion was adopted that the property rights clause in the South African constitution has to be changed to allow for expropriation of private property without compensation.

So, the state president, Cyril Ramaphosa, said that this would turn South Africa into the ultimate paradise and the Garden of Eden and Deputy President David Mabuza even went further saying that - basically threatening white farmers that if they do not voluntarily hand over their land to black people, then there would be a violent takeover. So, the situation is very dire in South Africa.

But the good news is that there is still a process that has to be followed and that's why we are in the United States.

CARLSON: What I find so striking is the response from everyone else around the world. It's almost never covered in the American media. There is a sense that the people being murdered deserve it because of what their ancestors did. And the international community is similarly silent.

Have you met with any government officials here in Washington about what's happening in your country?

ROETS: Well, that's why we are here. We are about to meet with some government officials and it's very unfortunate, the situation that you've just mentioned.

Especially in South Africa, there's a hierarchy of recognition. So, some people, when they are the victims, it's all over the news and you hear about it frequently. And other people, especially farmers in South Africa, white farmers in particular, they would be tortured to death and it would receive very little news coverage.

And that's unfortunately the situation abroad as well, which is why we are very grateful to be having this.

CARLSON: So, a government official in Australia said publicly maybe we ought to allow asylum to people being persecuted for their skin color in your country and he was basically laughed at and then attacked by your government for saying that.

ROETS: Yes, he was attacked. And they then said that he shouldn't say that because AfriForum was providing them with false information. Well, the information that we're quoting is government statistics.

So, that is the situation. Whoever speaks out against this - we, just for being in the United States, we've been accused of treason, we've had people threatening us, saying they will wait for us at the airport when we come back and they'll attack us and so forth. We had the state president today in parliament calling on us to go back to South Africa.

So, whenever you speak out against this, there is a very serious backlash.

CARLSON: This is not what Nelson Mandela wanted.

ROETS: No, it's the exact opposite than what he wanted. He spoke about a free country in which people were not judged by the color of their skin. And he even wanted farm attacks to be a priority crime.

He said that when he was president. And when his presidency was over, they deprioritized it.

CARLSON: So, you just watch something like this happen in a neighboring country, Zimbabwe, which went from being one of the richest in Africa to the poorest in the world because of farm attacks and because of the theft of private property, is the ANC, the ruling party in South Africa, aware of that lesson?

ROETS: Well, they are, but you know that saying real communism has never been tried. That's what they keep saying. So, it failed in Zimbabwe. It failed in Cuba. It failed in Venezuela. It failed in Russia. It failed in China. All of those countries.

And they are basically saying that we're going to try the same thing, but this time it's going to work.

CARLSON: So, last question. It's considered basically immoral in the United States to talk to you or to hear stories like this for reasons that nobody ever bothers really to explain, but it's just understood.

If you could speak to our media, to the people who are dismissing your claims as false, what would you say?

ROETS: Well, I think there are three things. Firstly, everything we say is fact based. It's based on research. But in terms of what we hope to achieve and what people can do, people who want to invest in South Africa, we want them to call on the South African government to say, listen, you are calling on us to invest in your country, but you want to expropriate those investments.

Number two, we are speaking with the US government and asking them to put pressure on the South African government, which could be done in a variety of ways.

And number three, members of the public and members of the media, the best thing that you can do to help us is to talk about this, to talk about it on public platforms and in that way to continue to put pressure on the South African government not to continue with this policy.

CARLSON: Just to tell the truth. I agree. Mr. Roets, thank you.

ROETS: Thanks very much. Thank you for being here.

BRETT LARSON, FOX NEWS "FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7" HOST: Hey, Tucker. Good to be here. We have been investigating this story over the past few days now, involving Facebook changes to how they handle news sources in user's news feed.

urn:contentItem:5SXN-FYB1-DXKX-053F-00000-00Tuesday News: So Much for N. Korea Not Being a Threat; Giuliani Completely Off the Deep End; Manafort Trial Kicks Off Today In Alexandria2018-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisTuesday News: So Much for N. Korea Not Being a Threat; Giuliani Completely Off the Deep End; Manafort Trial Kicks Off Today In Alexandria

Jul 31, 2018( Blue Virginia: http://bluevirginia.us/Delivered by Newstex) Facebook Twitter Google+ Pinterest WhatsAppby Lowell Here are a few national and Virginia news headlines, political and otherwise, for Tuesday, July 31. 65279;North Korea is working on new missiles, U.S. spy agencies say[1] Zimbabwe8217;s president, opponent both confident of win after close vote[2] Administration Mulls Unilateral Tax Cut for the Wealthy[3] (8220;The move would face a near-certain court challenge and could reinforce a liberal critique of Republican tax policy.8221; Just what rich people need, ANOTHER tax cut. Also, this seems wildly unconstitutional to me.) Donald Trump Willing to Meet Iranian President Hassan Rouhani 8216;Anytime They Want8217;[4] (That would go about as well as Trump8217;s disastrous meetings with our allies, with Putin, with Kim Jong-un, etc.) Rudy Giuliani on His Odd Cable News Blitz: I Was Trying to Kill a New York Times Story[5] (8220;Come Again?

8221;) Rudy Giuliani8217;s rambling new statements on Michael Cohen and the Trump Tower meeting, decoded[6] (Giuliani appears to have completely lost his mind.) The Memo: Trump is a risk to GOP in midterms[7] Trump8217;s Supreme Betrayal[8] (8220;Kavanaugh is, to put it bluntly, an anti-worker radical, opposed to every effort to protect working families from fraud and mistreatment.8221;) Trump Is Putting Indelible Conservative Stamp on Judiciary[9] (Liberals really don8217;t get the importance of the courts. It8217;s maddening.) Cohen may have the smoking gun[10] (8220;Republicans are really starting to go off the deep end.8221;) MSNBC legal expert: Cohen flipping puts Trump 8216;one witness away8217; from catastrophe[11] Trump smokescreen fogs up what is fact or fiction[12] (It8217;s known as gaslighting.) Sinclair stations have now aired four 8220;must-run8221; segments pushing for Brett Kavanaugh8217;s confirmation[13] (Do not watch WJLA-TV7/Sinclair 8220;news8221;) Watch Shepard Smith take down Rudy Giuliani8217;s 8220;straw man argument8221; that collusion isn8217;t a crime[14](8220;While the U.S. criminal code does not criminalize collusion, per se, it is a crime to conspire with a foreign adversary to influence or undermine our election8221;) Koch-backed study finds 8216;Medicare for All8217; would save U.S. trillions[15] (8220;An estimated cost of $32.6 trillion over 10 years is less than the US would spend over the next 10 years under the current system.8221;) Trump Loyalist Gets Surprise Fight From Democrat in Senate Race[16] (8220;Democratic former governor runs as pragmatist in Tennessee. Republican Marsha Blackburn vows to be unwavering Trump ally8221;) The 2020 Dem Class Is Already Frantically Making Moves Behind the Scenes[17] Trump Attacks 8216;Globalist8217; Koch Brothers, Saying He Doesn8217;t Need Their 8216;Money Or Bad Ideas8217;[18] (8220;The GOP megadonors have started distancing themselves from Trump.8221;) In a new book, Bob Woodward plans to reveal the 8216;harrowing life8217; inside Donald Trump8217;s White House[19] 10 states sue Trump administration to block 3D-printed guns[20] (Surprised Virginia isn8217;t a part of this.) Worker wages remain stagnant as wealthy executives are rolling in cash[21] (Wait, you mean a tax cut for rich people and big corporations isn8217;t 8220;trickling down?8221; But Trump and other Republicans like Corey Stewart PROMISED it would! LOL) 8216;It8217;s a significant shift in our thinking8217;: Business takes fresh look at Democrats[22] (8220;If businesses shift significant support away from Republicans, it could deal a blow to GOP fundraising. But some Democrats are skeptical that the talk will translate into cash for their campaigns.8221;) Paul Manafort8217;s Trial: Everything You Need to Know[23] (8220;Tuesday the first trial stemming from that investigation will kick off in Virginia. Former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort is facing 18 charges of bank and tax fraud, mostly related to his work as a political consultant in Ukraine prior to joining the campaign. The most explosive charges 8211; money laundering and failing to register as a foreign agent 8211; will be addressed in a second trial set to start in September in Washington, D.C.8221;) Tom Steyer8217;s $110 million plan to redefine the Democrats[24] (8220;Steyer is building out an operation that8217;s bigger than anyone other than the Koch Brothers 8212; and the billionaire and his aides believe the reservoir of non-traditional voters he8217;s already activated could become the overriding factor in House and other races across the country8230;Between the two organizations, he8217;ll have close to 1,000 people on staff, in addition to over 2,000 volunteers. The Need to Impeach email list alone has already topped 5.5 million8230;8217;Our list is bigger than the NRA8217;s 8212; and we8217;re going to make sure that it votes that way in 20188242;8221;) FEMA8217;s top HR official allegedly hired women as sexual partners for male employees[25] (8220;Corey Coleman is also accused of having sexual relations with female employees, allegations that date to 2015.8221; My god8230;) Trump is mad being president 8216;isn8217;t as fun as it should be8217; 8212; and it8217;s why he8217;s 8216;going bananas8217; online[26] What, Exactly, Makes This a 8216;Fringe8217; Position?[27] (8220;False equivalence strikes again in the pages of The New York Times.8221; In no way/shape/form is Stacey Abrams 8220;fringe8221;; the fact that the NY Times would equate her with extremist loon Brian Kemp is yet ANOTHER example of how the NY Times has lost its way.) Sen. Mark Warner proposes 20-point plan for cracking down on Big Tech[28] (8220;But breaking companies like Facebook up isn8217;t one of them.8221;) Sen. Mark Warner floats major tech company regulations that don8217;t include breakups[29] (I dunno, seems to me like Facebook in particular is inherently, deeply flawed.) Can Sexy Bigfoot Be Found in Virginia?[30] Corey Stewart, Watergate and a stretch that strains credulity[31] (8220;Poor Corey Stewart. The Republican U.S. Senate nominee, who promised a brutal, vicious, ruthless, and cutthroat campaign, says he8217;s being picked on by the media.8221; Corey is utterly pathetic.) Social media posts by consultant to Senate candidate Corey Stewart ridicule NAACP, black neighborhoods[32] Adviser to GOP Senate candidate Corey Stewart used expletive to describe majority-black cities[33] Trump intervenes in FBI headquarters project[34] Virginia requires campaign finance reform[35] (8220;Some of the commonwealth8217;s largest industrial leaders 8212; Altria, Dominion Energy, Virginia Bankers Association to name a few 8212; donate tens of thousands of dollars each year to General Assembly members in a system that leaves itself open to the peddling influence for deep-pocketed donors who make sure their candidates of choice are elected.8221;) Leading scholars quit U-Va. center over hiring of former Trump official[36] (8220;Leffler and Hitchcock wrote in their resignation letter that they would welcome Short to speak at the center. But granting him a senior fellowship position 8212; one they learned of through a press release 8212; runs 8216;counter to the Center8217;s fundamental values of nonpartisanship, transparency, openness, a passion for truth and objectivity, and civility.'8221; UVA has disgraced itself by doing this.) L.F. Payne and Frank Atkinson column: UVa8217;s appointment of ex-Trump aide advances academic integrity[37] (Uhhhhh8230;no.) Two Historians Resigned Over the Appointment of a Trump Flunky at UVA. They Were Right to Do So.[38] Hampton candidate, mayor take stand in federal trial[39] Northam picks longtime state employee to head HR agency[40] No prison for grandson of ex-Virginia governor in rape case[41] (How many types of privilege are involved here?) Hawley and Whyte column: State must take responsibility for problems related to gambling[42] Horse racing group asks Virginia regulators to loosen proposed rules on new gambling machines[43] Charlottesville teacher who took more than 100 8216;upskirt8217; photos of his students and produced child porn gets 23 years[44] Our cloudy, muggy, showery, stormy story continues[45] Facebook
