6.3 % Growth in EPS greater than RPS
EPS growth has consistently exceeded growth in RPS [Revenue Per Share].
EPS growth: Sequential EPS growth (Q2 vs Q1, 2020) was up 5.8% and PCP EPS growth (Q2 2020 vs Q2 2019) was up 97.8%. FY EPS growth (FY2019 vs FY2018) was down 15.3%.
RPS growth: Sequential growth in Revenue per share (Q2 vs Q1, 2020) was up 5.0% and PCP growth in Revenue per share (Q2 2020 vs Q2 2019) was up 10.5%. FY growth in Revenue per share (FY2019 vs FY2018) was up 28.6%.

- Reduction in total shares on issue.

Glossary

ADVT: Average Daily Volume of shares Traded
Annual Return: Dividends Paid In a 12-Month Period/Price at the Beginning of the Period + Capital Gain or Loss over 1 Year/Price 1 Year Ago (%)
Capital Gain/Loss from n Years Ago to n-1 Years Ago: Capital Gain or Loss over 1 Year/Price 1 Year Ago (%)
Current Ratio: Current Assets/Current Liabiliites (times)
EBIT Margin : Earnings Before Interest and Tax/Revenue (%)
Earnings Yield: Earnings Per Share/Share Price (%)
Moving Average Price (n periods): Sum of Prices for each Period/Number of Periods
PCP: Previous Corresponding Period
PV1000: Present value of 1000 invested 1 year/'n' years ago
Price Close/Moving Avg Price: Latest Price/Moving Average Price
Price/Earnings: Share Price/Earnings Per Share (times)
Price/NTA: Closing Share Price/Net Tangible Assets Per Share (times)
Price/Sales: Share Price/Sales Per Share (times)
Relative Price Change [RPC]: Relative price change is price change of stock with respect to Benchmark Index
Relative Strength (6 Months): Price close today/Price close 6 months ago, then ranked by percentile within the entire market.
Return on Assets: Net Profit/Total Assets (%)
Return on Equity (Shareholders' Funds): Net Profit/Net Assets (%)
TSR: Total Shareholder Returns is expressed as an annualized rate of return for shareholders after allowing for capital appreciation and dividend
TTM: Trailing 12 Months
Total Liabilities/Total Assets: Total Liabilities/Total Assets
Turnover Rate: value of annual trading volume as a percentage of market capitalisation
Volume Index (VI): Number of shares traded in the period/Average number of shares traded for the period
Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP): The Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is the summation of turnover divided by total volume in the same period.

The Daily Dose Europe "Headlines" edition aggregates banking, financial services and insurance headlines from the websites of a limited number of major European publication titles and newswires, with an editorial deadline of 6 a.m. London time. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WNB-BHG1-DXY4-X53M-00000-00Tulsi Gabbard, Democratic Presidential Candidate, Sues Google for $50 Million2019-07-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYTulsi Gabbard, Democratic Presidential Candidate, Sues Google for $50 MillionDaisuke Wakabayashi

The candidate claims Google shut down her ad account after the first debate in June, preventing her from capitalizing on new interest.

Representative Tulsi Gabbard, the long-shot presidential candidate from Hawaii, said in a federal lawsuit that Google infringed on her free speech when it briefly suspended her campaign’s advertising account after the first Democratic debate in June.

The lawsuit, filed on Thursday in a federal court in Los Angeles, is believed to be the first time a presidential candidate has sued a major technology firm.

[2020 Debates: Tulsi Gabbard qualifies for the next Democratic debate in October.]

In a twist that reflects Ms. Gabbard’s unorthodox political views, the claim that her speech was stifled by Google is similar to complaints made over the last year in Republican circles. Few Democrats have raised similar concerns.

Big tech companies like Google are getting increasing scrutiny by lawmakers and regulators around the world for a wide variety of issues, including their influence on political debate, their handling of consumer data, and the aggressive way they compete with smaller companies.

A day before the Gabbard lawsuit was filed, Facebook said the Federal Trade Commission had opened a formal antitrust investigation into its business practices. Earlier in the day, the F.T.C. announced that Facebook was fined a record $5 billion for deceiving users about their ability to control the privacy of their personal data.

Tulsi Now Inc., the campaign committee for Ms. Gabbard, said Google suspended the campaign’s advertising account for six hours on June 27 and June 28, obstructing its ability to raise money and spread her message to potential voters.

After the first Democratic debate, Ms. Gabbard was briefly the most searched-for candidate on Google. Her campaign wanted to capitalize on the attention she was receiving by buying ads that would have placed its website at the top of search results for her name.

The lawsuit also said the Gabbard campaign believed its emails were being placed in spam folders on Gmail at “a disproportionately high rate” when compared with emails from other Democratic candidates.

“Google’s arbitrary and capricious treatment of Gabbard’s campaign should raise concerns for policymakers everywhere about the company’s ability to use its dominance to impact political discourse, in a way that interferes with the upcoming 2020 presidential election,” the lawsuit said.

Ms. Gabbard and her campaign are seeking an injunction against Google from further meddling in the election and damages of at least $50 million.

Google has automated systems that flag unusual activity on advertiser accounts — including large spending changes — to prevent fraud, said Jose Castaneda, a spokesman for the company.

“In this case, our system triggered a suspension and the account was reinstated shortly thereafter,” he said. “We are proud to offer ad products that help campaigns connect directly with voters, and we do so without bias toward any party or political ideology.”

No other campaigns have publicly claimed that Google has suspended their advertising accounts.

Interest in Ms. Gabbard, who has served four terms in the House and is an Army National Guard veteran, spiked after the debate. She entered the presidential race as a relative unknown and is still polling at less than 1 percent, according to New York Times polling averages.

But her appeal has crossed traditional party lines. She has drawn support from both the right and the left because of a staunch antiwar message. She has also received favorable coverage from influential conservative news media like Drudge Report, Fox News and Breitbart.

Ms. Gabbard’s campaign is historic even in a race with many potential firsts. She was elected to the Hawaii House of Representatives when she was 21, becoming the youngest woman to join a United States state legislature. When she was elected as representative for Hawaii in 2012, she was the first Samoan-American and first Hindu member of Congress.

Her political views are unusual among Democratic candidates. She has a history of making anti-gay statements and worked for an anti-gay advocacy group run by her father. (She has since apologized and said her past views were wrong.)

And she has tapped into increasingly bipartisan passion: wariness of big tech. The lawsuit filed Thursday said Ms. Gabbard had joined Senator Elizabeth Warren, who is also vying to be the Democratic Party nominee, in   calling for large tech companies like Facebook, Google and Amazon to be broken up.

“Google’s discriminatory actions against my campaign are reflective of how dangerous their complete dominance over internet search is, and how the increasing dominance of big tech companies over our public discourse threatens our core American values,” Ms. Gabbard said in a statement. “This is a threat to free speech, fair elections, and to our democracy, and I intend to fight back on behalf of all Americans.”

While assertions of tech firms tipping the scales against political opponents are largely unproven, the lawsuit taps into concern that tech companies aren’t transparent about how decisions are made and they aren’t held accountable when things go wrong.

Last week, senators homed in on Google in a subcommittee hearing about censorship in search. The hearing aired many largely unproven claims that Google tilts search results against conservative viewpoints.

“Google’s control over what people hear, read, watch and see is unprecedented,” said Senator Ted Cruz, the Republican from Texas who led the subcommittee. “With that market power, Google can and often does control our discourse.”

Gabbard campaign workers sent an email to a Google representative on June 27 at 9:30 p.m. once they realized the account had been suspended. In emails reviewed by The New York Times, the campaign sent Google a screenshot of a notice of suspension for “problems with billing information or violations of our advertising policies.”

The account was reactivated at 3:30 a.m. on June 28. In the email announcing that it had reinstated the account, Google wrote that the company temporarily suspended the campaign’s account to verify billing information and policy compliance, but offered no other explanation for what had happened.

The campaign said it had opened the Google advertising account in February and had bought ads on Google search before the suspension. It said there was no problem with its billing information and that it had not violated Google’s terms of service.

“To this day, Google has not provided a straight answer — let alone a credible one — as to why Tulsi’s political speech was silenced when millions of people wanted to hear from her,” the lawsuit said.

Without the ads, the Tulsi 2020 website, which has links for donations and information about the goals of her candidacy, appears in the first page of search results for “Tulsi Gabbard.” But it is below stories and videos about her — selected by a Google algorithm — and after her Wikipedia page, her Twitter profile and her congressional website.

Roughly half of the candidates who participated in the first Democratic debates have bought ads to appear at the top of search results for their names.

With the exception of Senator Bernie Sanders, who is one of the leaders in fund-raising among the Democrats, the candidates buying Google search ads are polling in the low single digits, suggesting that the ads are more important to candidates with less name recognition.

Follow Daisuke Wakabayashi on Twitter: @daiwaka Nellie Bowles contributed reporting.

PHOTO: The presidential candidate Tulsi Gabbard said Google violated her free speech rights when it suspended her ad account after the Democratic debate in June. (PHOTOGRAPH BY DOUG MILLS/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WPD-HPP1-JCMN-Y248-00000-00Tulsi Gabbard vs. Google Goliath2019-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisTulsi Gabbard vs. Google GoliathRick Sterling

Jul 30, 2019( Antiwar.com Blog: http://www.antiwar.com/blog/ Delivered by Newstex) ; The Tulsi Gabbard presidential campaign has filed a major law suit against Google. This article outlines the main points of the law suit and evidence the social media giant Google has quietly acquired enormous influence on public perceptions and has been actively censoring alternative viewpoints. Tulsi Now vs. Google Tulsi Now, Inc.

vs. Google, LLC[1] was filed on July 25 in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California. The attorneys demand a jury trial and seek compensation and punitive damages of 'no less than $50 million'. Major points and allegations in the 36 page complaint include: Google has monopolistic control of online searches and related advertising. 'Google creates, operates, and controls its platform and services, including but not limited to Google Search, Google Ads, and Gmail as a public forum or its functional equivalent by intentionally and openly dedicating its platform for public use and public benefit, inviting the public to utilize Google as a forum for free speech. Google serves as a state actor by performing an exclusively and traditionally public function by regulating free speech within a public forum and helping to run elections.' (p22) 'Google has used its control over online political speech to silence Tulsi Gabbard, a candidate millions of Americans want to hear from. With this lawsuit, Tulsi seeks to stop Google from further intermeddling in the 2020 United States Presidential Election.. Google plays favorites, with no warning, no transparency - and no accountability (until now).' (p2) At a critical moment Google undercut the Tulsi Gabbard campaign.'On June 28, 2019 - at the height of Gabbard's popularity among internet researchers in the immediate hours after the debate ended, and in the thick of the critical post-debate period Google suspended Tulsi's Google Ads account without warning.' (p3) Google has failed to provide a credible explanation. The Tulsi campaign quickly sought to restore the account but 'In response, the Campaign got opacity and an inconsistent series of answers from Google To this day, Google has not provided a straight answer - let alone a credible one - as to why Tulsi's political speech was silence right when millions of people wanted to hear from her.' (p4) Google started by falsely claiming 'problems with billing'. Later, as reported in the NY Times story[2] a Google spokesperson claimed, 'Google has automated systems that flag unusual activity on advertiser accounts - including large spending changes - to prevent fraud.In this case, 'our system triggered a suspension.' ' Google has a corporate profit motive to oppose Tulsi Gabbard.'Google has sought to silence Tulsi Gabbard, a presidential candidate who has vocally called for greater regulation and oversight of (you guessed it) Google.' (p5) 'During her career in Congress, Gabbard has moved to limit the powers of big tech companies like Google and has fought to keep the Internet open and available to all. Gabbard has co-sponsored legislation that prohibits multi-tiered pricing agreements for the privileged few, and she has spoken in favor of reinstating and expanding net neutrality to apply to Internet firms like Google.' (p 8) Google's Actions have caused significant harm to the Gabbard campaign and violate the US and California constitutions and California business law. 'Through its illegal actions targeting Tulsi Gabbard, Google has caused the Campaign significant harm, both monetary (including potentially millions of dollars in forgone donations) and nonmonetary (the ability to provide Tulsi's important message with Americans looking to hear it).' (p6) 'Google engages in a pattern and practice of intentional discrimination in the provision of its services, including discriminating and censoring the Campaign's speech based not on the content of the censored speech but on the Campaign's political identity and viewpoint.' (p27) The public has an interest in this case. 'Unless the court issues an appropriate injunction, Google's illegal and unconstitutional behavior will continue, harming both the Campaign and the general public, which has an overwhelming interest in a fair, unmanipulated 2020 United States Election cycle. (p 34) Google Explanation is Not Credible The Tulsi Gabbard Google Ads account was abruptly suspended at a crucial time. The question is why. Was it the result of 'unusual activity' triggering an 'automatic suspension' as claimed by Google? Or was it because someone at Google changed the software or otherwise intervened to undermine the Tulsi campaign? Google's explanation of an 'automatic suspension' from 'unusual activity' is dubious. First, the timing does not make sense. The sudden rise in searches on 'Tulsi Gabbard' began the day before the suspension. Gabbard participated in the first debate, on June 26. Her presence and performance sparked interest among many viewers. Next morning, June 27, media reported that, 'Tulsi Gabbard was the most searched candidate on Google after the Democratic debate in Miami'.[3] The second debate took place in the evening of June 27. With discussion of the Democratic candidates continuing, Tulsi Gabbard continued to attract much interest. Around 9:30 pm (ET) on June 27 the Google Ads account was suddenly suspended. If the cause was 'unusual activity', the 'automatic trigger' should have occurred long before. Second, Google was fully aware of the 'unusual activity'. In fact Google was the source of the news reports on the morning of June 27. Reports said, 'According to Google Trends, Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren was the most searched candidate heading into the debate After the debate, Gabbard vaulted into first.' Third, it is hard to believe that Google does not have any human or more sophisticated review before suspending a major Ads account on a politically intense night. It should have been obvious that the cause of increased interest in Gabbard was the nationally televised Democratic candidates debate and media coverage. Fourth, the changing explanation for the sudden suspension, starting with a false claim that there were 'problems with billing', raises questions about the integrity of Google's response. Google Secretly Manipulates Public OpinionUnknown to most of the public, there is compelling evidence that Google has been secretly manipulating search results to steer public perception and election voting for years. Dr. Robert Epstein, former editor-in-chief of Psychology Today, has been studying and reporting on this for the past six years. Recently, on June 16, 2019 he testified[4] before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the Constitution. His testimony is titled 'Why Google Poses a Serious Threat to Democracy, and How to End That Threat'. Epstein has published 15 books and over 300 scientific and mainstream media articles on artificial intelligence and related topics. 'Since 2012, some of my research and writings have focused on Google LLC, specifically on the company's power to suppress content - the censorship problem, if you will - as well as on the massive surveillance the company conducts, and also on the company's unprecedented ability to manipulate the thoughts and behavior of more than 2.5 billion people worldwide.' As shown by Dr. Epstein, Google uses several techniques to manipulate public opinion. The results of an online search are biased. Search 'suggestions' are skewed. Messages such as 'Go Vote' are sent to some people but not to others. Epstein's written testimony[5] to Congress includes links to over sixty articles documenting his research published in sites ranging from Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences to Huffington Post. Epstein's testimony describes 'disturbing findings' including: 'In 2016, biased search results generated by Google's search algorithm likely impacted undecided voters in a way that gave at least 2.6 million votes to Hillary Clinton'. (Epstein notes that he supported Clinton.) 'On Election Day in 2018, the 'Go Vote' reminder Google displayed on its home page gave one political party between 800,000 and 4.6 million more votes than it gave the other party.' 'My recent research demonstrates that Google's 'autocomplete' search suggestions can turn a 50/50 split among undecided voters into a 90/10 split without people's awareness.' 'Google has likely been determining the outcomes of upwards of 25 percent of the national elections worldwide since at least 2015. This is because many races are very close and because Google's persuasive technologies are very powerful.' Google is Censoring Alternative Media In August 2017 TruePublica reported their experience and predictions in an article titled 'The Truth War is Being Lost to a Global Censorship Apparatus Called Google'[6]. The article says, '60 percent of people now get their news from search engines, not traditional human editors in the media. It is here where the new information war takes place - the algorithm. Google now takes 81.2 percent of all search engine market share globally. Google has the ability to drive demand and set the narrative, create bias and swing opinion.' In 2017, the World Socialist Web Site (wsws.org) reported[7] that, 'In April, under the guise of combating 'fake news', Google introduced new procedures that give extraordinary powers to unnamed 'evaluators' to demote web pages and websites. These procedures have been used to exclude the WSWS and other antiwar and oppositional sites. Over the past three months, traffic originating from Google to the WSWS has fallen by approximately 70%. In key searches relevant to a wide range of topics the WSWS regularly covers - including the U.S. military operations and the threat of war, social conditions, inequality and even socialism - the number of search impressions has fallen dramatically.' ; In essence, Google has 'de-ranked' and is screening alternative and progressive websites from researchers. WSWS lists many progressive websites along with the dramatic decline in reader visits following the changes at Google. The article includes numerous specific examples such as this one: 'Searches for the term 'Korean war' produced 20,932 impressions in May. In July, searches using the same words produced zero WSWS impressions.' 'The policy guiding these actions is made absolutely clear in the April 25, 2017 blog post by Google's Vice President for Engineering, Ben Gomes, and the updated 'Search Quality Rater Guidelines' published at the same time. The post refers to the need to flag and demote 'unexpected offensive results, hoaxes and conspiracy theories' - broad and amorphous language used to exclude any oppositional content. 'The 'lowest' rating is also to be given to a website that 'presents unsubstantiated conspiracy theories or hoaxes as if the information were factual.'' Tulsi Gabbard has not only called for much stricter regulations on high tech and social media giants. She has also challenged the Democratic Party and foreign policy establishment. In late February 2016 she resigned[8] as vice-chair of the Democratic National Committee to support candidate Bernie Sanders against the establishment favorite, Hillary Clinton. Gabbard has issued sharp criticisms of US foreign policy. Recently she said[9], 'We hear a lot of politicians say the same argument that we've got to stay engaged in the world otherwise we'll be isolationists as though the only way the United States can engage with other countries is by blowing them up or strangling them with economic sanctions by smashing them and trying to overthrow their governments. This is exactly what's wrong with this whole premise and the whole view in which too many politicians, too many leaders in this country are viewing the United States role in the world.'ConclusionDid Google take the next step from silently censoring websites the corporation does not like to undercutting a presidential candidate the corporation does not like? This is a David vs. Goliath story. Google/Alphabet is the 37th largest corporation in the world with enormous political influence in Washington. Whether or not the law suit succeeds, it may serve the public interest by exposing Google's immense monopolistic power and illustrate the need for much more regulation, transparency and accountability. It may also generate more interest in Gabbard's message and campaign in the face of efforts to silence her. Rick Sterling is an investigative journalist based in the San Francisco Bay Area. He can be contacted at rsterling1@gmail.com[10]; https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/facebook?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.antiwar.com%2Fblog%2F2019%2F07%2F30%2Ftulsi-gabbard-vs-google-goliath%2F...kname=Tulsi%20Gabbard%20vs.%20Google%20Goliathhttps://www.addtoany.com/add_to/twitter?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.antiwar.com%2Fblog%2F2019%2F07%2F30%2Ftulsi-gabbard-vs-google-goliath%2F...kname=Tulsi%20Gabbard%20vs.%20Google%20Goliathhttps://www.addtoany.com/add_to/whatsapp?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.antiwar.com%2Fblog%2F2019%2F07%2F30%2Ftulsi-gabbard-vs-google-goliath%2F...kname=Tulsi%20Gabbard%20vs.%20Google%20Goliathhttps://www.addtoany.com/add_to/reddit?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.antiwar.com%2Fblog%2F2019%2F07%2F30%2Ftulsi-gabbard-vs-google-goliath%2F...kname=Tulsi%20Gabbard%20vs.%20Google%20Goliathhttps://www.addtoany.com/add_to/linkedin?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.antiwar.com%2Fblog%2F2019%2F07%2F30%2Ftulsi-gabbard-vs-google-goliath%2F...kname=Tulsi%20Gabbard%20vs.%20Google%20Goliathhttps://www.addtoany.com/add_to/tumblr?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.antiwar.com%2Fblog%2F2019%2F07%2F30%2Ftulsi-gabbard-vs-google-goliath%2F...kname=Tulsi%20Gabbard%20vs.%20Google%20Goliathhttps://www.addtoany.com/add_to/email?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.antiwar.com%2Fblog%2F2019%2F07%2F30%2Ftulsi-gabbard-vs-google-goliath%2F...kname=Tulsi%20Gabbard%20vs.%20Google%20Goliathhttps://www.addtoany.com/add_to/print?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.antiwar.com%2Fblog%2F2019%2F07%2F30%2Ftulsi-gabbard-vs-google-goliath%2F...kname=Tulsi%20Gabbard%20vs.%20Google%20Goliathhttps://www.addtoany.com/share#url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.antiwar.com%2Fblog%2F2019%2F07%2F30%2Ftulsi-gabbard-vs-google-goliath%2F...le=Tulsi%20Gabbard%20vs.%20Google%20GoliathThe post Tulsi Gabbard vs. Google Goliath[11] appeared first on Antiwar.com Blog[12]. urn:contentItem:5WPF-HHN1-F03R-N1YN-00000-00Tulsi Gabbard vs Google Goliath2019-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisTulsi Gabbard vs Google GoliathRick Sterling

Jul 31, 2019( Dissident Voice: http://www.dissidentvoice.org Delivered by Newstex) Introduction The Tulsi Gabbard presidential campaign has filed a major law suit against Google. This article outlines the main points of the law suit and evidence the the social media giant Google has quietly acquired enormous influence on public perceptions and has been actively censoring alternative viewpoints. Tulsi Now vs Google Tulsi Now, Inc vs Google, LLC[1] was filed on July 25 in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California. The attorneys demand a jury trial and seek compensation and punitive damages of 'no less than $50 million'. Major points and allegations in the 36 page complaint include: * Google has monopolistic control of online searches and related advertising.

'Google creates, operates, and controls its platform and services, including but not limited to Google Search, Google Ads, and Gmail as a public forum or its functional equivalent by intentionally and openly dedicating its platform for public use and public benefit, inviting the public to utilize Google as a forum for free speech. Google serves as a state actor by performing an exclusively and traditionally public function by regulating free speech within a public forum and helping to run elections.' (p. 22) 'Google has used its control over online political speech to silence Tulsi Gabbard, a candidate millions of Americans want to hear from. With this lawsuit, Tulsi seeks to stop Google from further intermeddling in the 2020 United States Presidential Election.. Google plays favorites, with no warning, no transparency - and no accountability (until now).' (p. 2) * At a critical moment Google undercut the Tulsi Gabbard campaign. 'On June 28, 2019 - at the height of Gabbard's popularity among internet researchers in the immediate hours after the debate ended, and in the thick of the critical post-debate period Google suspended Tulsi's Google Ads account without warning.' (p. 3) * Google has failed to provide a credible explanation. The Tulsi campaign quickly sought to restore the account but 'In response, the Campaign got opacity and an inconsistent series of answers from Google To this day, Google has not provided a straight answer - let alone a credible one - as to why Tulsi's political speech was silence right when millions of people wanted to hear from her.' (p. 4) Google started by falsely claiming 'problems with billing'. Later, as reported in the NY Times story[2] a Google spokesperson claimed, 'Google has automated systems that flag unusual activity on advertiser accounts - including large spending changes - to prevent fraud.In this case, 'our system triggered a suspension.' ' * Google has a corporate profit motive to oppose Tulsi Gabbard. 'Google has sought to silence Tulsi Gabbard, a presidential candidate who has vocally called for greater regulation and oversight of (you guessed it) Google.' (p. 5) 'During her career in Congress, Gabbard has moved to limit the powers of big tech companies like Google and has fought to keep the internet open and available to all. Gabbard has co-sponsored legislation that prohibits multi-tiered pricing agreements for the privileged few, and she has spoken in favor of reinstating and expanding net neutrality to apply to Internet firms like Google.' (p. 8) * Google's Actions have caused significant harm to the Gabbard campaign and violate the U.S. and California constitutions and California business law. 'Through its illegal actions targeting Tulsi Gabbard, Google has caused the Campaign significant harm, both monetary (including potentially millions of dollars in forgone donations) and nonmonetary (the ability to provide Tulsi's important message with Americans looking to hear it).' (p. 6) 'Google engages in a pattern and practice of intentional discrimination in the provision of its services, including discriminating and censoring the Campaign's speech based not on the content of the censored speech but on the Campaign's political identity and viewpoint.' (p. 27) * The public has an interest in this case. 'Unless the court issues an appropriate injunction, Google's illegal and unconstitutional behavior will continue, harming both the Campaign and the general public, which has an overwhelming interest in a fair, unmanipulated 2020 United States Election cycle. (p. 34) Google Explanation is Not Credible The Tulsi Gabbard Google Ads account was abruptly suspended at a crucial time. The question is why. Was it the result of 'unusual activity' triggering an 'automatic suspension' as claimed by Google? Or was it because someone at Google changed the software or otherwise intervened to undermine the Tulsi campaign? Google's explanation of an 'automatic suspension' from 'unusual activity' is dubious. First, the timing does not make sense. The sudden rise in searches on 'Tulsi Gabbard' began the day before the suspension. Gabbard participated in the first debate, on June 26. Her presence and performance sparked interest among many viewers. Next morning, June 27, media reported that, 'Tulsi Gabbard was the most searched candidate on Google after the Democratic debate in Miami[3]'. The second debate took place in the evening of June 27. With discussion of the Democratic candidates continuing, Tulsi Gabbard continued to attract much interest. Around 9:30 pm (ET) on June 27 the Google Ads account was suddenly suspended. If the cause was 'unusual activity', the 'automatic trigger' should have occurred long before. Second, Google was fully aware of the 'unusual activity'. In fact, Google was the source of the news reports on the morning of June 27. Reports said: 'According to Google Trends, Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren was the most searched candidate heading into the debate After the debate, Gabbard vaulted into first.' Third, it is hard to believe that Google does not have any human or more sophisticated review before suspending a major Ads account on a politically intense night. It should have been obvious that the cause of increased interest in Gabbard was the nationally televised Democratic candidates debate and media coverage. Fourth, the changing explanation for the sudden suspension, starting with a false claim that there were 'problems with billing', raises questions about the integrity of Google's response. Google Secretly Manipulates Public Opinion Unknown to most of the public, there is compelling evidence that Google has been secretly manipulating search results to steer public perception and election voting for years. Dr. Robert Epstein, former editor-in-chief of Psychology Today, has been studying and reporting on this for the past six years. Recently, on June 16, 2019 he testified[4] before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the Constitution. His testimony is titled 'Why Google Poses a Serious Threat to Democracy, and How to End That Threat'. Epstein has published 15 books and over 300 scientific and mainstream media articles on artificial intelligence and related topics. 'Since 2012, some of my research and writings have focused on Google LLC, specifically on the company's power to suppress content - the censorship problem, if you will - as well as on the massive surveillance the company conducts, and also on the company's unprecedented ability to manipulate the thoughts and behavior of more than 2.5 billion people worldwide.' As shown by Dr. Epstein, Google uses several techniques to manipulate public opinion. The results of an online search are biased. Search 'suggestions' are skewed. Messages such as 'Go Vote' are sent to some people but not to others. Epstein's written testimony[5] to Congress includes links to over sixty articles documenting his research published in sites ranging from Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences to Huffington Post. Epstein's testimony describes 'disturbing findings' including: 'In 2016, biased search results generated by Google's search algorithm likely impacted undecided voters in a way that gave at least 2.6 million votes to Hillary Clinton'. (Epstein notes that he supported Clinton.) 'On Election Day in 2018, the 'Go Vote' reminder Google displayed on its home page gave one political party between 800,000 and 4.6 million more votes than it gave the other party.' 'My recent research demonstrates that Google's 'autocomplete' search suggestions can turn a 50/50 split among undecided voters into a 90/10 split without people's awareness.' 'Google has likely been determining the outcomes of upwards of 25 percent of the national elections worldwide since at least 2015. This is because many races are very close and because Google's persuasive technologies are very powerful.' Google is Censoring Alternative Media In August 2017 TruePublica reported their experience and predictions in an article titled 'The Truth War is Being Lost to a Global Censorship Apparatus Called Google[6]'. The article says: 60 percent of people now get their news from search engines, not traditional human editors in the media. It is here where the new information war takes place - the algorithm. Google now takes 81.2 percent of all search engine market share globally. Google has the ability to drive demand and set the narrative, create bias and swing opinion. In 2017, the World Socialist Web Site (wsws.org) reported[7] that: In April, under the guise of combating 'fake news', Google introduced new procedures that give extraordinary powers to unnamed 'evaluators' to demote web pages and websites. These procedures have been used to exclude the WSWS and other anti-war and oppositional sites. Over the past three months, traffic originating from Google to the WSWS has fallen by approximately 70%. In key searches relevant to a wide range of topics the WSWS regularly covers - including the U.S. military operations and the threat of war, social conditions, inequality and even socialism - the number of search impressions has fallen dramatically. In essence, Google has 'de-ranked' and is screening searchers from seeing alternative and progressive websites such as truepublica, globalresearch, consortiumnews, commondreams, Wikileaks, truth-out and many more. WSWS reported numerous specific examples such as this one: 'Searches for the term 'Korean war' produced 20,932 impressions in May. In July, searches using the same words produced zero WSWS impressions.' 'The policy guiding these actions is made absolutely clear in the April 25, 2017 blog post by Google's Vice President for Engineering, Ben Gomes, and the updated 'Search Quality Rater Guidelines' published at the same time. The post refers to the need to flag and demote 'unexpected offensive results, hoaxes and conspiracy theories' - broad and amorphous language used to exclude any oppositional content. 'The 'lowest' rating is also to be given to a website that 'presents unsubstantiated conspiracy theories or hoaxes as if the information were factual.'' Tulsi Gabbard has not only called for much stricter regulations on high tech and social media giants. She has also challenged the Democratic Party and foreign policy establishment. In late February 2016 she resigned[8] as vice-chair of the Democratic National Committee to support candidate Bernie Sanders against the establishment favorite, Hillary Clinton. Gabbard has issued sharp criticisms of US foreign policy. Recently she said[9]: We hear a lot of politicians say the same argument that we've got to stay engaged in the world otherwise we'll be isolationists as though the only way the United States can engage with other countries is by blowing them up or strangling them with economic sanctions by smashing them and trying to overthrow their governments. This is exactly what's wrong with this whole premise and the whole view in which too many politicians, too many leaders in this country are viewing the United States role in the world. Conclusion Did Google take the next step from silently censoring websites the corporation does not like to undercutting a presidential candidate the corporation does not like? This is a David vs Goliath story. Google/Alphabet is the 37th largest corporation in the world with enormous political influence in Washington. Whether or not the law suit succeeds, it may serve the public interest by exposing Google's immense monopolistic power and illustrate the need for much more regulation, transparency and accountability. It may also generate more interest in Gabbard's message and campaign in the face of efforts to silence her. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:4TH4-8G90-TX7B-W017-00000-00Turbulent Economic Times2008-09-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisMIKE DUFFY LIVE PRIME TIME20:00:00 ETMIKE DUFFYTurbulent Economic Times

MIKE DUFFY: Welcome back in to "Mike Duffy Live". Just checking the financial ticker. Not very good news, the market melting down, triple digit losses. There's panic selling greeps, grips the TSX and the American markets keep getting worse. How will Canada fair? What should we do? Let's bring in an expert, John Curtis of the Centre for International Governance and Innovation. He's an expert on global finance, and spent a lifetime at the department of foreign affairs looking at the world economy. John, what's your take on what we've seen in the last few days? How does it affect Canadians, and what should we do?

JOHN CURTIS (Centre for International Governance and Innovation): Mike, good evening. Markets tend to be very volatile, especially when there's a lack of confidence, and our basic financial markets are rooted in confidence. If you are willing to accept a dollar, that's because it is, we have confidence it's worth a dollar.

DUFFY: Yeah, in God we trust, or whatever the Americans say.

CURTIS: All that kind of stuff. All that kind of stuff. So confidence is key. So therefore, if people get nervous, they oversell. If they get overly confident, they buy too much, and so as exchange rates go, as stock markets go, things tend to move up and down, but on the whole, in the end of the day, there's equil... what we call in economics, equilibrium. Things level out, and...

DUFFY: Now in the United States, we saw mortgage companies, and some of them are in very deep trouble, giving mortgages, I read somewhere, some guy in jail got a mortgage on a big house. How was he going to pay the mortgage from jail? He didn't have a job. He couldn't go to work, and yet the greed of that market at that time in that housing bubble allowed that to happen, but it didn't happen here, why?

CURTIS: We admire, often, the risk taking that Americans take. We always complain about ourselves being a little too cautious, a little risk averse. In fact, as history is showing us, it's not too bad to be a little on the cautious side. We would, that person would not have got a loan of that sort in Canada.

DUFFY: Because our rules are stronger. Our banks are more conservative, and the superintendent of financial insists...

CURTIS: All that, and our culture is a little more cautious, if I can use those terms. We just don't gamble so much as the Americans do, and, so therefore, as I say, we didn't have the big tech boom that they had in the end of the '90s, so we didn't go as high as the American economy went. On the other hand, we're not going to go as low as they go when things start to unwind very quickly.

DUFFY: So when people are sitting home tonight watching "Mike Duffy Live" and wondering about their RRSPs, and all of that stuff, what's your advice?

CURTIS: Hang on. It's going to, it's going to turn around. In fact, probably within the next few weeks, you'll see things being turned around. The American dollar has already turned around, as we've seen over the last month. There'll be stability built back into the, the market, and this is in fact a good time to start buying, the financial assets. If you buy low...

DUFFY: If you've spare cash.

CURTIS: Exactly. So, it is a worry. I mean, we can't underestimate it. This is something that your parents, my parents and our grandparents went through in the '30s, but governments know more what to do. International institutions are out there, which they weren't before. People around the world in institutions deal with each other now much better than before. People aren't putting up trade barriers in response to these financial troubles. The governments getting involved, even the free enterprise American government. We have good regulation. So in fact, it's going to stabilize.

DUFFY: It's a safer world.

CURTIS: It's a safer world.

DUFFY: Interesting to see the free enterprise American government with one, running such a huge deficit, and two, bailing out financial firms that should know better, but that's their political agenda.

CURTIS: All politics are local, Mike.

DUFFY: That's it.

CURTIS: Yeah.

DUFFY: Thank you very much. John Curtis, a financial expert. Great to have you in, and we'll have you back often as this unfolds, and I'll hold you to it. It's all going to come back, so don't panic.

CURTIS: Exactly.

DUFFY: Right on.

CURTIS: Thank you, Mike.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5MD6-XDS1-JB20-G38C-00000-00Turf Battles in the Intel World; McConnell Pushes Back Trump Tax Plan; Toddler Science2016-12-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:49ZLexisNexisKENNEDY8:00 PM ESTBryan Suits, Brian Brenberg, Andy Levy, Peter Suderman, Katherine Magnu-WardNEWSDomestic121301cb.234Turf Battles in the Intel World; McConnell Pushes Back Trump Tax Plan; Toddler ScienceLisa Kennedy Montgomery

LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FBN HOST: All right, the brouhaha over why Russia hacked the election apparently opening some old wounds in the intelligence community. The worry now that it could lead to the turf battles that defined the intel world prior to 9/11. And here's why. We're told the CIA and FBI cannot agree on a motive for this hacking. The CIA reportedly believes Russia tried to get Trump elected; the FBI won't go quite that far. And this has lawmakers on both sides of the aisle very upset.

Here with more, he knows how the world really works. It's Bryan Suits, KFI AM 640 radio host in Los Angeles. It's the dark secret place. Great show. Bryan is also a combat war veteran from Iraq and Bosnia. Bryan, welcome back.

BRYAN SUITS, RADIO HOST, KFI AM: It's beginning to look a lot like Chris Nukka (ph) out here.

KENNEDY: I don't know what that means, but it's probably funny. So let's talk a little bit about the CIA. CIA says we know the motive Russia wanted to get Trump elected. The FBI says the evidence is quote, fuzzy and ambiguous. Why the disagreement between law enforcement and intelligence?

SUITS: Well, the CIA should have said they wanted disruption in the election process, because that is what the Russians sought and that's what they achieved. The FBI's culture is a investigative law enforcement culture. They need to line up all the ducks in a row and hand it to a prosecutor who then goes 12 and 0 with a jury. They don't have a disinformation branch of the FBI. They're the opposite of disinformation which would be information.

The CIA is one of their primary functions, and I know as an information operations guy in Iraq, in general, we were instructed to tell the truth. Personally of my own volition, I planted disinformation in 2005 by saying things like, Muqtada al-Sadr was on the CIA payroll, things like that. It was on me, just me. I'll take the hit on that. But that's the difference.

The CIA is an intelligence agency, including some counterintelligence functions. The FBI, by the way, their job -- if this is going on in the U.S. or externally and it's targeting the U.S., the FBI, one of their key functions is counterintelligence, and they missed it.

KENNEDY: So why should we believe the CIA? If part of their job is disinformation, why should we automatically believe them?

SUITS: I think because of the outcome. What we have with here is the largest political divide in our lifetimes, probably within 100 years --

KENNEDY: OK, well let's talk about the outcome, because this is something that I think is really important to address. There's a big difference between hacking e-mails and putting out fake news and actually screwing around with votes and voting machines.

SUITS: Yes, and this is where --

KENNEDY: And there's a natural assumption that somehow if there was disruption, that it affected the vote. But it may have only affected perception, but people have the free will to choose whichever candidate they want.

SUITS: Yes, and that's why the CIA and the Democrats need to stop saying hack, hack, hack. It was disruption. The SVR, the Russians weaponized ignorance, and you got people who were politically active for the first time in their life who don't know the difference between Sputnik International and Drudge or CNN or BBC, and that was the key. And by the way, the Democrats --

KENNEDY: But was it, though? Do you really think there were enough people who were influenced by fake news stories to change the electoral outcome of the election? That's my ultimate question --

SUITS: I don't.

KENNEDY: -- because I think in some ways that's really disingenuous and insulting to voters.

SUITS: Yes. No, I don't, but I do think that there was a critical mass of people maybe just in the bubble who were either rejecting Hillary because of fake things, besides her just being a loathsome person --

KENNEDY: But there were plenty of real things in the foier (ph), the outcomes in the e-mail server scandal.

SUITS: Yes. But I mean when you have something under its own momentum that gets a guy to come to a pizza restaurant. You know, there was a real issue. And part of the thing is this has nothing to do with doing anything illegal. It's perfectly legal to put up a fake website or to influence the American voters.

KENNEDY: Yes.

SUITS: People -- Americans need to be cognizant of the fact that in 2011, Putin blames us for political instability after their election.

KENNEDY: Yes.

SUITS: So turn about is fair play. This has been on his plate for five years.

KENNEDY: And it's also not the first time that Russia has caused disruption in elections outside their country. The question is, does it affect the outcome of the race? At this point I don't see enough evidence that it does. I don't have a problem with there being a congressional investigation, but I think it's premature to come to those massive and hysterical conclusions. Last word.

SUITS: Yes, no, I agree. And if the Democrats Debbie Wasserman Schultz's resignation go without mentioning that somebody externally messed with a private organization called a political party in America, if they -- if that came and went, they discouraged all those Bernie voters, then that's on them.

By the way, if the Republicans think that by 6 p.m. on January 20, the Reince Priebus to Jeb Bush Donald Trump oppo research doesn't get released, then they're really naive about who this guy is, Putin.

KENNEDY: I love naivete. Bryan Suits, thank you so much.

Coming up, Donald Trump wants to take a chain saw to tax rates, but Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, he's pushing back. We'll tell you why some Republicans are fighting against tax cuts. Brian Brenberg breaks it down in moments.

KENNEDY: Maybe they're going home because they're on strike because they're communists. Thank you, Weezer.

Welcome back. President-elect Donald Trump's tax cut plan looks to be heading for a big showdown on Capitol Hill, but this time not only with Democrats but Republicans too. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell last night said he does not want any tax cuts to add to the deficit, and that could pour some cold water on one of Trump's biggest campaign promises, a $1 trillion infrastructure plan to fix the nation's roads and bridges.

So how do you pay for all those things while also cutting taxes? There's only one man who can break it down for us. That's Brian Brenberg. He's the Associate Professor of Business and Economics, Chair of the Program in Business and Finance at the Kings College. This is Brianomics.

So we all want great roads. We all want neat stuff. We all want tax cuts. This President-elect does not want to cut military spending or entitlement spending. We've talked about this a little bit before. Do you share Mitch McConnell's reservations?

BRIAN BRENBERG, ASSOCIATE PROFESSOR OF BUSINESS AND ECONOMICS, KINGS COLLEGE: I am so glad that Mitch McConnell is saying this. Look, people are saying this is bad news and it's a fight between the president and Congress. No, this is actually really good news. What McConnell's saying is, we want to get tax cuts done, and it's only going to happen if we do it responsibly, if we pay for it, because we're not going to pass $5 trillion more in debt onto our children. So I actually like that he's saying this because he wants to get something done. He wants to get it done quick. He wants to get even some bipartisan participation on this. So he's saying, let's find a way to do it.

LISA KENNEDY, HOST: Well how do you that? How do you make it revenue neutral?

BRENBERG: Well one, OK - -

KENNEDY: I mean, that's what's McConnell's talking about.

BRENBERG: No. You have to be careful here, because when Republicans say revenue neutral, they're also saying, look, we know that when you cut taxes you're going to spur growth. When you spur growth, more tax revenue is going to come in.

KENNEDY: So they're just going to go ahead and spend the new taxes.

BRENBERG: Well, it's - - what - - they're saying there's going to be some revenue feedback here. But the other thing you have to do, you have to reform spending and you have to go after entitlements. There's just no other way to do it. Trump did not want to talk about on the campaign trail. I like that McConnell is pushing him in that direction. I think Paul Ryan's going to push him in that direction. And I think they're going to say to him, look, if you're the negotiator-in-chief, here's your next job. You've got to negotiate with the American people.

KENNEDY: Sure.

BRENBERG: You're going to negotiate with the Democrats in Congress. You've got to help us find a way to get some spending reform done as well.

KENNEDY: Well, it - - it's interesting because we may be also headed for a personal showdown. Because Mitch McConnell's wife is the nominee to be Secretary of Transportation, and she will be in charge of this $1 trillion infrastructure spending plan that Republicans and Libertarians laughed at Bernie Sanders for floating.

BRENBERG: Yes. And - - and look, there's some real problems with that. I've come on here and said this before. I'm weary of big infrastructure spending, even when we talk about it being funded by the private sector which Trump is saying - -

KENNEDY: (Inaudible) because if there's tax hand outs and subsidies - -

BRENBERG: There are a lot of details there that we haven't seen and at the end of the day the government's going to be on the hook for this. I agree there's going to be a showdown there. But again, I think McConnell and Ryan can push Trump to look at some long term entitlements spending reform that can give him a little bit of room to breathe when it comes to these tax cuts. I'm not a big fan of infrastructure, but it might also give him some room to breathe in infrastructure as well.

KENNEDY: All right. Well he - - he may have to pear down his wish list on infrastructure spending.

BRENBERG: Yes. Yes, exactly.

KENNEDY: And most certainly have to cut entitlement and military spending. And at the same time, they have to figure out how to service that debt. Because, we cannot have the debt double under this incoming president the way it did under Obama and Bush the younger.

BRENBERG: No. I mean, Trump is inheriting deficits are going to rise to over $1 trillion in just a few years. And - - and you know, his tax plan right now, again, if you don't look at this, the revenue that might come in because he's cutting taxes. It adds $5 trillion to the debt, so you're right. You're talking about over the next 10 years, potentially worst case scenario, $15 trillion more in debt added. It's - - it's immoral to pass that on to our children. We absolutely cannot do that. That's why it's imperative from Trump to work with Ryan, work with McConnell and reform spending, Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security.

KENNEDY: Yes, absolutely. I mean, you've also called it a huge social justice issue. The debt burden that we've got, which we will touch on another day. Merry Christmas Brian Brenberg. I know you are off with your family very soon. So thank you for a year of insight, intelligence and Brianonimcs (ph).

BRENBERG: It was my pleasure. Thank you.

KENNEDY: Thanks man. All right, coming up a new study says, we can predict that toddlers will grow up to be productive citizens or total criminals. And if it's true, do we really want that kind of power?

The party panel, we'll let the parents here. We're going to all hash it out next.

KENNEDY: We're all clapping down here, party people. Welcome back.

When stashing away funds for your child's future, it's important to know whether you'll need college tuition or bail money. In a study conducted by Duke University and King's College of London, tests done on children at a very young age, just three years old, can determine whether they will turn to a life of crime in their older years. The procedure is examine the child's language and motor skills, as well as frustration, tolerance and impulsivity. So can we save our society by putting these troubled toddlers behind bars. The party panel is back. Katherine Mangu-Ward, Andy Levy, and Julie Banderas.

All right Julie, you've got three children, congratulations. Which one is the criminal?

(LAUGHTER)

JULIE BANDERAS, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Oh, definitely the middle child.

KENNEDY: Nice.

BANDERAS: She's three. And so, when I think about this, she just turned four, but they test frustration tolerance. No three and a half year old has tolerance for anything. And then restlessness and impulsivity, I can't get her to sit still long enough to take a test like this. So she's definitely the, she'll be in prison at some point. But I'm not sure I buy into this test. I just don't know how much you can actually test a three year old.

KENNEDY: Well they tested thousands of people in New Zealand over the course of several decades. And followed their lives and figured out health records and criminal and welfare records. And they noted that - that the 20 percent of society, who tends to use 80 percent of societies public resources, they're the ones who essentially failed the test. What does it say to you?

ANDY LEVY, CO-HOST FNC RED EYE WITH GREG GUTFELD: Well, look, it sounds absurd - - at first I thought it sounded absurd. I thought it sounded scary. It sounded like some sort of Gattica type thing, where we're going to, you know, genetically test kids at the age of three and determine their life.

KENNEDY: But it's not - -

(CROSSTALK)

LEVY: And that's the thing. The point that I - - that I latched on to was they said, researchers concluded that low cognitive test scores for skills such as language indicated less developed brains. Possibly caused by too little stimulation in their early life. In other words, this isn't all we've discovered a method to determine which three year olds are worthless. It's a - - we've developed a method that shows how we might, you know, get these kids on a path towards not becoming criminals or a drain on society.

KENNEDY: And future children, maybe you stimulate them in this way parent.

(CROSSTALK)

KENNEDY: I mean, there's an upside here. There's always an upside for the eternal optimist that is Katherine Mangu-Ward.

KATHERINE MANGU-WARD, EDITOR IN CHIEF, REASON MAGAZINE: That's true. No. Actually in this case, I also have a three year old and so I, of course went clicking on this link before I even read the rest of the headline. So my thing is that, even if there is some kind of health upshot, the public policy upshot is almost certainly disastrous. If we're doing something early on and then categorizing people in any official capacity as the probable consumers of social services, in the form of prison and disability, whatever. It - - it, like, that doesn't end well, that story doesn't end well. That story (inaudible), you're right to go full, like science fiction dystopia on that.

KENNEDY: What happens if you get some sort of mark, in a public medical file? And all our medical files - -

(CROSSTALK)

KENNEDY: - - are going to be made public once we - -

WARD: No problem at all.

(CROSSTALK)

WARD: Give people a sub-par designation.

KENNEDY: Yes. Yes. This person has a greater likelihood of being a drain on society.

WARD: And I think the framing is what really actually raises the red flag for me. The idea that they initially set out to investigate this idea about the cradle principle of the 80/20 principle. You know, if it's - - if this is about who's using up the resources. That, to sort of approach it from that perspective, I think it's a very different thing to say, hey should we tell parents.

KENNEDY: I have my own 80/20 principle and that is eat 80 percent of your calories in the first 20 percent of the day. Many of today's teens, they don't have the munchies so they don't eat like that.

WARD: I don't either.

KENNEDY: But they will certainly have more time for crime, because they seem to be putting down the bottle, the butts and the bongs. Alcohol, drug and cigarette use amongst most American teens at an all time low. And, of course, this is a good sign for our nation's future. Or, could we be led by a bunch of nerds when we're old people.

Julie, it used to be that the teenagers, they were smoking grass. They were stealing their parents hooch.

BANDERAS: Are you speaking for yourself, or just in general?

KENNEDY: Like totally general. It's not a thing - -

BANDERAS: Because that time that my mom didn't walk on me, walk in to my bedrooms smoking a bong. That didn't happen. But she ended up actually taking it to the police station because she didn't know what it was. I said I was smoking tobacco and she told the cops. And she's like, my daughter, this was in her, and they looked at her and they laughed and confiscated it. That didn't happen.

(CROSSTALK)

BANDERAS: I think that honestly to just more intense helicopter parenting, like me. I have webcams in my kids rooms. And I will put chips, microchips under their necks when they start to leave the home.

(CROSSTALK)

LEVY: OK. All this stuff is so purported. So, we don't know if they're smoking, drinking or doing drugs.

(CROSSTALK)

LEVY: Or it could be also that President-elect Trump is already getting results.

KENNEDY: That's right.

LEVY: So we don't know.

KENNEDY: Just say niegn (ph).

LEVY: Exactly.

WARD: I'm thrilled that American teenagers are lame. But I think it's pretty obvious that they're just substituting, like, Snapchat for smoking. Right? So anytime that someone's starts to feel like, ah, I'm really worried about screen time. No. Far better screen time than any of the alternatives.

KENNEDY: Yes. Opiod addiction.

LEVY: I do think also, you should wait until you're an adult to start numbing yourself from the effects of life. I mean, just, you know, be an adult and then yes. Just - -

(CROSSTALK)

KENNEDY: I mean, do you have anything to numb the effects?

LEVY: The show's almost over right?

KENNEDY: Yes.

LEVY: Yay, we'll talk in a minute.

(CROSSTALK)

LEVY: What you need? What you need?

KENNEDY: Whatever you got baby. Julie, Andy and Katherine, thank you so much as Katherine looks to the heavens.

WARD: There's no help for me there.

(LAUGHTER)

KENNEDY: Coming up, Donald Trump today met with Kanye West. Tomorrow he's meeting with the giants of the tech sector. What the President-elect has up his sleeve, Peter Suderman, computer man explains in a moment.

KENNEDY: No, another surreal moment in the Trump transition, when the President-elect hugged it out with rapper Kanye West. Look at them. After the two of them had a closed door meeting in Trump Tower, according to E!, they discussed "Jeezy" becoming some kind of entrepreneurial ambassador.

Well tomorrow Apple and other tech giants are going to meet with the President-elect at Trump Tower. You might recall, that during the campaign, Donald Trump chastised Apple for outsourcing jobs to China and refusing to work with intelligence agencies to break their encryption codes. Will the computer moguls find common ground with Trump? Let me ask Peter Suderman, Reason Magazine's features editor and he's also the author of this segment, Suderman, Computerman. Peter, welcome back.

PETER SUDERMAN, EDITOR REASON MAGAZINE: Glad to be here. Thanks for having me.

KENNEDY: So will Kanye West be the Ambassador to Italy? The post that Chris Christie's seems to have thumbed his nose at.

SUDERMAN: I mean, what do we know about Kanye West is that he shops so much. He can speak Italian, so I think he's really a great candidate here. What do you think Donald Trump's favorite Kanye West album is? Probably not "808's and Heartbreak" I'm thinking. But look, this is the kind of thing that we're going to see in the Trump Administration. Trump is, he is a TV star. He's a pop star. He's somebody who sort of hangs out in these weird worlds and he's going to combine these things in ways we're kind of not used to seeing.

KENNEDY: Oh, certainly. No. I think it's fascinating. I think that what Donald Trump is orchestrating at Trump Tower, you never know who's coming or going. It's like this ongoing party scene from "Breakfast at Tiffany's", and it's the most curious mix of people.

Now, speaking of curious mix, he's going to have Tim Cook, Sheryl Sandberg, Elon Musk, Larry Page, Jeff Bezos, who he's been very critical of, all coming to Trump Tower for this big tech symposium. What are they possibly going to cover? There's a lot of animosity both ways. Will they be able to bridge the gap?

SUDERMAN: I mean, this is an olive branch on the part of the tech community, which was quite critical, I mean in terms of both of the companies themselves. But really even the staffers, the kinds of people who work for these big tech companies are just not going to be Donald Trump fans as a general rule. And Donald Trump was in, for his part, really quite critical of a bunch of these companies.

Apple, as you said and in particular he went after Jeff Bezos, the, who also owns the Washington Post, accused him of using the Washington Post to influence getting lower tax rates and to cover him in ways that Trump said were bad and irresponsible. But the thing is, these companies are, make up a huge part of the economy and they are really highly regulated. They are really dependent on, as a direction of how government regulations and how they go.

(CROSSTALK)

KENNEDY: - - taxes, trade, manufacturing. But I think what it really comes down to is who runs the world? And I think that's what they're going to fight over. So, I will pose that question to you, between the tech moguls and Donald Trump. Who runs the world?

SUDERMAN: Well Donald Trump certainly thinks he runs the world, and would like to, would like everyone else to think that. And, you know, I hope that the results of this is - - is that that it's not quite the case and that we actually end up in a - - in a - - a world that is a little more driven by individual choices using things like technology. And I really, I mean, honestly I feel like this is necessary given all the business that these companies have that is up for, kind of, grabs for being messed with by the administration, by the government.

KENNEDY: Yes.

SUDERMAN: But it's really unfortunate. Because we are now sort of - -

KENNEDY: This will be - -

SUDERMAN: - - a situation in which corporations have to work with the government, have to, kind of, go and beg for indulgences from the President of the United States in order to get their business done.

KENNEDY: Oh, it's like the old school church, before the great schism. Peter Suderman, thank you very much for your insight.

SUDERMAN: Thanks for having me.

KENNEDY: I hear technology is the future.

Coming up, are teddy bears doing too much ecstasy at dance parties? Or not enough? Find out the proper dosage in the Topical Storm, next.

KENNEDY: When your cabin is besot. Besot I say, with gremlins, come to me and I'll domesticate them and teach them how to fetch newspapers. This is the Topical Storm, your haven for weird news.

Topic number one, we all know the old adage, a healthy teddy bear is a happy teddy bear. Just watch this little guy break some moves.

(VIDEO CLIP)

KENNEDY: A lot of people assume teddy bears have to jog to stay fit, but dancing actually burns quite a few calories too. Plus dancing is a skill your teddy can learn and improve upon for the rest of his life. So be sure to feed your teddy bear a diet rich in Omega 3 and fatty acids, and avoid sugar and fried foods. Because then, your teddy bear might have to get open heart surgery.

(VIDEO CLIP)

(LAUGHTER)

KENNEDY: (Inaudible)

Topic number two. The fresh smell of winter is a magical moment for pets who find their world coated in a blanket of frozen weirdness.

(VIDEO CLIP)

KENNEDY: Yes. Dog nails him. Show it again. Good.

(LAUGHTER)

KENNEDY: That is such a good dog. Oh, don't worry, the cat found peace and seclusion away from the dog up on a beautiful mountain.

(VIDEO CLIP)

KENNEDY: It was a beautiful "meowtain". Get it?

Topic number three. This is a Fox Business breaking news alert. We have some fresh video from Senator John McCain and Secretary of State nominee Rex Tillerson. They're meeting on Capital Hill as we speak. Those inside the meeting said McCain was a real baby, but stood up to corporative dinosaur Tillerson. Let's watch.

(VIDEO CLIP)

KENNEDY: See, they see eye to eye. I know, I know it's evening and I have the up most respect for Senator McCain. But wearing onesie jammies to such an emposium sort of lacks decorum. A lot of big feelings in that room. It's going to be what it's like on Capital Hill. I can't wait.

Topic number four. Nothing says Christmas quite like coming together with your loved ones, sharing the warmth of the season and basking in the glow of the Yule log on a glorious HD surround sound environment. But hey, drift less hobo's celebrate the holidays too. Let's not be hoboist. And that's why this year we have substituted, substituted the Yule log with a soothing dumpster.

(VIDEO CLIP)

KENNEDY: Yes. Great description for this election season. It really was a dumpster fire, and it is the reason for the season. But there's no need to fear for all you pyrophobes out there. We've got our Santa Tracker 3000 working overtime and it appears Santa's annual fire truck tour through rural America has brought him to the dumpster to extinguish the flames at this very moment. Let's check in with him now to see how his night is progressing. Santa?

(VIDEO CLIP)

KENNEDY: Sorry you had to see that. It's OK. He pulled himself out with his own wee. And that we cannot show on a family broadcast. Though I'm going to watch it later for a few hours.

Topic number five. I love Star Wars, and I have a French bulldog. So this one is really for me. You know Rogue One is coming out Friday. So allow me to present Rogue Two, a pair of French bulldogs who are baffled by a Star Wars icon, watch.

(VIDEO CLIP)

KENNEDY: They want to like Yoda, because they know the Jedi master is essentially a French bulldog. Look at those pointy ears, flat face and wrinkled forehead. But the dogs are all, what's up with the bi peedles (ph) and the green wand old midget Harry Potter? Yes. I wish they'd torn him limb from limb. I love Yoda, he's my favorite character, but still it would be pretty good to see. It's a fake Yoda.

Well let's check in with my dog Lemmy (ph), and see if he likes Star Wars. There's Lemmy (ph) and Zucchini (ph) with a great thing ding. Thing a ling, a ding, ding , ding dong. Fly paper. You know the force is strong with that one. His mediclorions (ph) are off the charts.

Thank you so much for watching the show tonight. Please follow me on Twitter and Instagram at Kennedynation Facebook. It's Kennedyfbn, Kennedyfbn@foxbusiness.com use hash tag "Topical Storm".

Airing tomorrow night on the show. Sandra Smith, Dana Pareno and Greg Gutfeld. It is a regular beauty pageant and I'm going to crown one of them. Thank you for being my mistress.

Good night.
